subsection.text: In this article, unless the context requires otherwise, the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Any state” means:

paragraph.text: Any state, possession, or territory of the United States;
The District of Columbia; and
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

subsection.text: “County” means a county of this State and includes Baltimore City.
“County board” means the board of education of a county and includes the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners.
“County superintendent” means the county superintendent of schools of a county and includes the Chief Executive Officer of the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners.
“Department” means the State Department of Education.
“Elementary and secondary education” means education and programs of education from and including preschool through the end of high school and their equivalent.
“Includes” or “including” means includes or including by way of illustration and not by way of limitation.
“Person” includes:

paragraph.text: An individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, executor, administrator, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, public or private corporation, or other entity; and
The State, any county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of this State, and any of their agencies or units.

subsection.text: “Property” means any real or personal property or any interest in real or personal property.
“Public schools” means the schools in the public elementary and secondary education system of this State.
“State Board” means the State Board of Education.
“State Superintendent” means the State Superintendent of Schools.

section.text: There shall be throughout this State a general system of free public schools according to the provisions of this article.
Unless Baltimore City expressly is excepted, the provisions of this article apply to Baltimore City.
There is a State Department of Education, established as a principal department of the State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the State Board of Education.
The State Board is organized and has the general powers and duties as provided in Subtitle 2 of this title.

Acting under the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the State Board, the State Superintendent is responsible for the administration of the Department and has general supervision of all professional and clerical assistants of the Department.
The State Superintendent shall be appointed and has the general powers and duties as provided in Subtitle 3 of this title.
The following professional assistants shall be appointed to the Department:

paragraph.text: No more than three Deputy State Superintendents of Schools;
Any assistant State superintendents and directors authorized by the State Board and provided in the State budget; and
Any other professional assistants and agents authorized by the State Board and provided in the State budget.

From the nominees proposed by the State Superintendent, the State Board shall appoint all professional assistants to the Department, who shall be in the executive service, management service, or special appointments in the State Personnel Management System.
With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall set the qualifications for each professional position.
The State Superintendent may transfer professional assistants within the Department as necessary.
All professional assistants shall serve at the pleasure of the State Board and the State Superintendent.
All other professional assistants shall be removed in accordance with procedures set by the State Board.
In addition to the other duties specified in this section, each professional assistant to the Department has the duties assigned to him by the State Superintendent.
The Deputy State Superintendent designated by the State Superintendent or by the State Board is the acting State Superintendent when the State Superintendent is absent or disabled.
Assistant State superintendents and directors have charge of the various divisions of the Department.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise provided by law, the State Superintendent shall appoint and remove all clerical assistants and other nonprofessional personnel of the Department in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the skilled service, with the exception of special appointments.
The credential secretary and statistician of the Department are special appointments in the State Personnel Management System.

section.text: The Department has authority over:

paragraph.text: Matters of elementary and secondary education that affect this State; and
The general care and supervision of public elementary and secondary education.

section.text: There is a State Board of Education in the Department.

subsection.text: The State Board consists of 11 regular members, and 1 student member, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.text: In making appointments to the State Board, the Governor shall consider representation from:

subparagraph.text: All parts of this State; and
Areas of this State with concentrations of population or unique needs.

paragraph.text: The members of the Board shall be appointed from the general public.
The following individuals may not be appointed to the Board:

subparagraph.text: Except for the student member, any individual who is subject to the authority of the Board;
The Governor; and
The State Superintendent.

paragraph.text: The student member shall be selected by the Governor from a list of 2 persons nominated by the Maryland Association of Student Councils.
The student member shall be:

subparagraph.text: A regularly enrolled student; and
In good standing in a public high school in the State.

paragraph.text: The student member may attend and participate in an executive session of the Board.
The student member may not vote on any matter that relates to:

subparagraph.text: The dismissal of or other disciplinary action involving personnel; or
Appeals to the State Board under § 2–205, § 4–205, or § 6–202 of this article.

paragraph.text: Each regular member serves for a term of 4 years and until a successor is appointed and qualifies. These terms are staggered as required by the terms of the members serving on the State Board as of July 1, 1989.
The Governor shall appoint a new member to fill any vacancy on the Board for the remainder of that term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member is eligible for reappointment but may not serve for more than two full 4-year terms.
The student member shall serve for a term of 1 year. A student member is eligible for reappointment but may not serve more than two full 1-year terms.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member of the State Board for:

paragraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Incompetency; or
Willful neglect of duty.
Before removing a member, the Governor shall send the member a copy of the charges against him and give him an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the member requests a hearing within the 10-day period:

subparagraph.text: The Governor promptly shall hold a hearing, but a hearing may not be set within 10 days after the Governor sends the member a notice of the hearing; and
The member shall have an opportunity to be heard publicly before the Governor in his own defense, in person or by counsel.

subsection.text: If a member is removed, the Governor shall file in the office of the Secretary of State:

paragraph.text: A complete statement of all charges made against the member;
The findings of the Governor as to the charges; and
A complete record of the proceedings.
Each year, the State Board shall hold:

subparagraph.text: A meeting in July; and
At least three other regular meetings.

paragraph.text: The Board may hold special meetings as necessary.
At the annual Board meeting in July, the State Board shall select a president and a vice president from among its members.
A member may not serve for more than 4 years as president.
The State Superintendent is the Chief Executive, Secretary, and Treasurer of the State Board.
He shall attend each meeting of the Board and of its committees, except when his own tenure, salary, or the administration of his office are under consideration.
He may advise the Board on any question under consideration, but may not vote.

subsection.text: A member of the State Board serves without compensation but is entitled to reimbursement for expenses in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations.
The affirmative vote of a majority of the members then serving on the State Board is required for any action by the Board.
In addition to the other powers granted and duties imposed under this article, the State Board has the powers and duties set forth in this section.
The State Board shall:

paragraph.text: Determine the elementary and secondary educational policies of this State; and
Cause to be carried out those provisions of this article that are within its jurisdiction.
The State Board shall adopt bylaws, rules, and regulations for the administration of the public schools.
These bylaws, rules, and regulations have the force of law when adopted and published.

The bylaws, rules, and regulations apply to each county. However, they do not apply to Baltimore City to the extent that they relate to matters that are the subject of other provisions of this article that do not apply to Baltimore City.

subsection.text: The State Board may institute legal proceedings to enforce:

paragraph.text: The provisions of this article that are within its jurisdiction; and
The bylaws, rules, and regulations adopted by the Board.
Without charge and with the advice of the Attorney General, the State Board shall explain the true intent and meaning of the provisions of:

subparagraph.text: This article that are within its jurisdiction; and
The bylaws, rules, and regulations adopted by the Board.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection and in Title 6, Subtitles 4 and 5 of this article, the Board shall decide all controversies and disputes under these provisions.
The decision of the Board is final.

subparagraph.text: The Public School Labor Relations Board shall decide any controversy or dispute arising under Title 6, Subtitle 4 or Subtitle 5 of this article.
A decision of the Public School Labor Relations Board is final.

subsection.text: As Secretary to the State Board, the State Superintendent may administer oaths to witnesses in any matter before the Board.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply to Baltimore City to the extent that it relates to matters that are the subject of other provisions of this article that do not apply to Baltimore City.
Through the State Superintendent, the State Board shall exercise general control and supervision over the public schools and educational interests of this State.
Through the State Superintendent, the Board shall consult with and advise county boards, county superintendents and their staffs, principals, teachers, and interested citizens.
The Board shall seek in every way to direct and develop public sentiment in support of public education.
With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall establish basic policy and guidelines for the program of instruction for the public schools.
The policy and guidelines shall be printed in sufficient quantities to provide copies to:

subparagraph.text: Public school officials and teachers;
Private schools; and
Interested citizens of this State.

paragraph.text: The State Board of Education shall require the establishment of criteria in each county for the selection of applicants for enrollment in public secondary school career and technology education programs. Enrollment criteria developed for this purpose shall ensure equal access to programs.
With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall investigate:

subparagraph.text: The educational needs of this State; and
Methods to improve educational conditions.

paragraph.text: If necessary, the Board may employ additional expert assistance for these investigations.
The State Board shall send the Governor an annual State public school budget including, subject to the Maryland Constitution and existing laws, the appropriation for:

subparagraph.text: The Department; and
State aid to the counties for current expenses, for student transportation and for the construction of school buildings.

paragraph.text: The budget shall be certified by the State Superintendent before it is sent to the Governor.

subsection.text: The State Board shall:

paragraph.text: Consider the educational needs of this State; and
With the advice of the State Superintendent, recommend to the Governor and the General Assembly any legislation that it considers necessary.
On the recommendation of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall establish standards and guides for planning and constructing school building projects.
These standards and guides shall be used as the basis for reviewing plans and specifications submitted to the State Superintendent for approval.
The State Board shall maintain a school construction planning service to:

subparagraph.text: Assist in the development and review of preliminary and final plans and specifications for any public school building project and the educational program that it is designed to house; and
Advise county boards as to the suitability of these construction plans on the basis of educational effectiveness, construction, and reasonable economy of costs.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall collect, publish, and distribute to the county boards information on school construction procedures, methods, and materials.
In this subsection, “professional employee” means an employee:

subparagraph.text: For whom a certificate has been issued by the State Superintendent; and
For whom a salary scale has been established by law for the position or who meets or exceeds the qualifications required for an established salary scale.

paragraph.text: From time to time, the State Board shall adopt bylaws, rules, and regulations that establish a minimum ratio of professional employees to students enrolled in the public schools or any combination of grades in these schools.
The ratio established by the State Board for the total number of professional employees for each county, calculated to the nearest whole position on a pro rata basis, may not be more than:

subparagraph.text: 46 for each 1,000 of the first 5,000 students enrolled as of September 30 of each year; and
45 for each additional 1,000 students.

paragraph.text: A county may employ more professional employees than the number permitted in this subsection as it considers necessary.
At least 95 percent of the permitted number of professional employees shall be assigned to public schools.

subsection.text: With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall require each private educational association, corporation, and institution to report annually, on or before August 31, its enrollment and courses of study on the forms that the Board provides.

paragraph.text: With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall specify the information each county board, school official, and teacher is to record and shall require the following information to be recorded:

subparagraph.text: All financial accounts, including the annual budget; and
All educational records.

paragraph.text: The reports containing this information shall be made on the form that the State Board, with the advice of the State Superintendent, requires.
If the State Superintendent agrees, the required information may be sent in automatic data processing, machine–usable form.
The State Board shall submit an annual report to the Governor on:

subparagraph.text: All operations of the Department;
The support, conditions, progress, and needs of elementary and secondary education in this State; and
The overall plan for elementary and secondary education in this State.

paragraph.text: This annual report shall be printed in sufficient quantities for general distribution in this State.
The State Board shall coordinate the overall growth and development of elementary and secondary education in this State.
In consultation with the State Superintendent, the State Board shall develop and periodically update an overall plan consistent with the bylaws that shall identify:

subparagraph.text: The present and future needs of elementary and secondary education throughout the State, including a discussion of the demographic composition of the elementary and secondary population;
The present and future capabilities of the public elementary and secondary education system in this State;
The short–range and long–range objectives and priorities for elementary and secondary education and methods and timelines for achieving and maintaining them;
Whether current programs adequately prepare graduates for employment opportunities in this State, or postsecondary education opportunities;
The status and needs of the career and technology education program, the vocational rehabilitation program, and the library system of these programs;
The technological advancements that would enhance elementary and secondary education throughout the State;
Methods to upgrade and improve teacher education and teacher certification programs;
The school systems that have dropped below the statewide test averages and shall assess the options available to improve the test averages of these school systems;
The methods to improve the diagnosis of basic reading skill deficiencies of elementary and secondary school students and to improve the literacy rates of these students;
The methods to increase the rate of retention and graduation of secondary school students;
The short–range and long–range objectives for the resolution of the problem of substance abuse by elementary and secondary school students; and
The short–range and long–range objectives for the resolution of the problems of youth and teenage pregnancy.

subsection.text: In this section, “noncollegiate educational institution” means a school or other institution that offers an educational program but is not an institution of postsecondary education, as defined in § 10-101 of this article.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: Apprenticeship and on-the-job training programs that are subject to the approval of the Apprenticeship and Training Council;

Individuals or entities that offer or arrange for instruction solely for avocational purposes through courses in areas such as art, music, dance, drama, sports, crafts, or photography, if these courses are designed primarily for developing skills for personal enrichment, recreation, or other leisure pursuits; or

Individuals or entities that offer or arrange for a supplemental educational program or tutoring in subjects usually taught in an elementary or secondary school to students concurrently enrolled in public or nonpublic schools.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to these individuals or entities specified in subparagraph (1)(ii) of this subsection solely on the basis that they use the word “school” as a part of their name, in literature or publications such as advertisements, brochures, catalogs or bulletins, or in other pronouncements.

subsection.text: With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall adopt bylaws, rules, and regulations for the approval and accreditation of all public schools.

With the advice of the State Superintendent, the State Board shall establish minimum requirements for issuing certificates and diplomas by public and private noncollegiate educational institutions in this State.

paragraph.text: A noncollegiate educational institution may not operate in this State without a certificate of approval from the State Board.

The State Board shall issue a certificate of approval to a noncollegiate educational institution if it finds that the facilities, conditions of entrance and scholarship, and educational qualifications and standards are adequate and appropriate for:

subparagraph.text: The purposes of the institution;
The programs, training, and courses to be taught by the institution; and
The certificates and diplomas to be issued by it.

paragraph.text: The State Board may not issue a certificate of approval to an institution that practices discrimination based on race, color, or national origin.

This subsection does not apply to an institution operated by a bona fide church organization, including the Amish and Mennonite church parochial schools. However, an institution that does not have a certificate of approval from the State Board may not receive State funds, except that an institution operated by a bona fide church organization is not required to have a certificate to receive State funds for eligible students in the food service program who are enrolled in nursery school through the eighth grade.

If the State Board believes that a noncollegiate educational institution that applies for a certificate of approval does not meet the conditions or standards necessary for the issuance of the certificate, it shall give the institution written notice of the specific deficiencies.

Within 20 days of receipt of a notice of deficiencies, the institution may request a hearing before the Board, and, within 60 days of receipt of the request, the Board shall hold a hearing to determine if the certificate of approval should be issued.

If, within 6 months from the date on which the application for certification was submitted to the State Board, the institution has received neither a certificate of approval under subsection (e) of this section nor written notice of deficiencies under this subsection, it may request, within 20 days, a hearing before the Board to determine if the certificate of approval should be issued.

If the State Board believes that a noncollegiate educational institution does not meet the conditions or standards on which its certificate of approval was based, it shall give the institution written notice of this belief.

The notice shall specify the alleged deficiencies and direct the institution to correct them within a period of not less than 30 days as set by the Board. If the institution requests a hearing within 20 days of the notice, the Board shall hold a hearing to determine the matter.
The order to correct the deficiencies shall be stayed until a determination is made after the hearing.
The State Board may order a noncollegiate educational institution to end operations if the institution fails to correct the specified deficiencies within the period set by the Board and if:

subparagraph.text: A hearing is not requested; or
After a hearing, the Board finds that the institution does not meet the conditions or standards.

paragraph.text: The order takes effect 15 days after it is issued.
An institution has the right to judicial review of any State Board determination under this section as provided by the Administrative Procedure Act.
The decision of the State Board is presumed correct and proper and the institution has the burden of proving otherwise.
The State Board shall be a party to the proceeding.

subsection.text: A noncollegiate educational institution shall:

paragraph.text: Be open for inspection by the State Superintendent or his designee at all reasonable times; and
Furnish the reports and information required by the State Superintendent on the forms provided by the State Superintendent.

Each noncollegiate educational institution that receives notice of a contaminated drinking water supply from the institution’s supplier of water, in accordance with § 9-410 of the Environment Article or otherwise, shall send notice of the drinking water contamination to the parent or legal guardian of each student attending the institution.
The notice shall:

subparagraph.text: Be sent by the institution within 10 business days after receipt of the notice of contamination from the institution’s water supplier;
Be in writing;
Identify the contaminants and their levels in the institution’s water supply; and
Describe the institution’s plan for dealing with the water contamination problem until the institution’s water is determined by the appropriate authority to be safe for consumption.

paragraph.text: The State Board shall consider an institution’s failure to send the notice required under this subsection in determining whether the institution continues to meet the conditions or standards on which the institution’s certificate of approval is based.

subsection.text: Each noncollegiate educational institution affiliated with a residential child care program or treatment facility shall comply with the provisions of Title 8, Subtitle 5 of this article.

A nonpublic school that is subject to the requirements of this title may not hire or retain any employee who works with or has access to students and who the school knows has been convicted of a crime involving:

paragraph.text: An offense under § 3–307 of the Criminal Law Article;

Child sexual abuse under § 3–602 of the Criminal Law Article, or an offense under the laws of another state that would constitute child sexual abuse under § 3–602 of the Criminal Law Article if committed in this State; or

A crime of violence as defined in § 14–101 of the Criminal Law Article, or an offense under the laws of another state that would be a violation of § 14–101 of the Criminal Law Article if committed in this State.

subsection.text: The State Board shall revoke the certificate of approval or letter of tentative approval of a nonpublic school that violates this section.

paragraph.text: There is a Public Education Partnership Fund.
The Fund shall be used to:

subparagraph.text: Enhance cooperation between the private sector and public education entities;
Facilitate the expansion and development of new partnership initiatives;
Encourage the donation of corporate and foundation money to expand the outreach capacity of the Department; and
Strengthen the development of family and community involvement in public education.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall credit to the Public Education Partnership Fund any money that is received from public grants and private contributions.

The State Board, upon the recommendation of the State Superintendent, may use money that is credited to the Public Education Partnership Fund for any activity or program that furthers the purposes listed in subsection (a)(2) of this section, including:

paragraph.text: Preparation and distribution of information packets and brochures;
Development of public service announcements;
Development of seminars and training programs focusing on public education priorities;
Development of a family and community involvement hot line;
Establishing appropriate award systems for the recognition of educators and business contributors; and
Evaluating and recommending methods to improve the efficiency and promote the growth of private sector and public education partnerships.

subsection.text: The Treasurer shall invest money from the Public Education Partnership Fund for the use of the Fund, and all earnings shall be credited to the Fund.

Expenditures from the Fund shall be made pursuant to an appropriation approved by the General Assembly in the annual State budget or by the budget amendment procedure provided for in § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that:

paragraph.text: Is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
May not be used as a substitute for State General Fund appropriations.

subsection.text: The Public Education Partnership Fund is subject to audit by the Legislative Auditor as provided under § 2-1220 of the State Government Article.

section.text: There is a State Superintendent of Schools in the Department.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent shall be appointed by the State Board for a term of 4 years beginning on July 1 after his appointment and serves until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The State Board shall fix his salary and pay it from the appropriation for the expenses and maintenance of the Department.
The State Superintendent shall:

paragraph.text: Be an experienced and competent educator;
Be a graduate of an accredited college or university;
Have at least 2 years of special academic and professional graduate preparation in an accredited college or university; and
Have at least 7 years of experience in teaching and administration.
The State Board may remove the State Superintendent for:

subparagraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Insubordination;
Incompetency; or
Willful neglect of duty.

paragraph.text: Before removing the State Superintendent, the State Board shall send the Superintendent a copy of the charges against him and give him an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the State Superintendent requests a hearing within the 10-day period:

subparagraph.text: The State Board promptly shall hold a hearing, but a hearing may not be set within 10 days after the State Board sends the State Superintendent a notice of the hearing; and
The State Superintendent shall have an opportunity to be heard publicly before the State Board in his own defense, in person or by counsel.

subsection.text: The State Board shall appoint a new State Superintendent to fill a vacancy in that office for the remainder of the unexpired term.
In addition to the other powers granted and duties imposed under this article, the State Superintendent has the powers and duties set forth in this section.

paragraph.text: The State Superintendent shall enforce the provisions of:

subparagraph.text: This article that are within his jurisdiction; and
The bylaws, rules, and regulations of the State Board.

paragraph.text: If an educational institution or county board violates any of these provisions, the State Superintendent, by written notice, may require the State Comptroller to withhold from that institution or board:

subparagraph.text: All or any part of an appropriation made by the General Assembly; and
All or any part of any other payment from funds budgeted by the State.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent shall:

paragraph.text: Carry out the educational policies of the State Board;
Call and conduct conferences of county boards and professional personnel of the county school systems on the condition, needs, and improvement of the schools; and
Prepare and publish pamphlets to:

subparagraph.text: Stimulate public interest;
Promote the work of education; and
Foster professional insight and efficiency in teachers.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent is a member of the Governor’s Executive Council.
The State Superintendent shall:

paragraph.text: Receive and examine each report required under the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the State Board; and
Examine the expenditures, business methods, and accounts of each county board and advise each county board about them.
Subject to the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the State Board, the State Superintendent shall approve or disapprove each:

subparagraph.text: Proposal for the purchase or sale of any ground, school site, or building;
Plan or specification for the remodeling of a school building if the remodeling costs more than $350,000;
Plan or specification for the construction of a new school building; and
Change order that costs more than $25,000 for the remodeling, restoration, or construction of a school building.

paragraph.text: If the State Superintendent disapproves any plan, specification, proposal, or change order, he shall state in writing the reasons for his disapproval.
If the construction is to be done by a county board, the board may not begin until the plans and specifications are approved in writing by the State Superintendent.
If the construction is to be done by contract, the contract is invalid without the written approval of the State Superintendent.

The State Superintendent shall certificate the professional personnel in each public school in accordance with this article and subject to the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the Professional Standards and Teacher Education Board.
Renewal requirements for any professionally certificated employee may be waived if:

subparagraph.text: The renewal is recommended by the county superintendent having jurisdiction over the employee; and
The professionally certificated employee is:

sub-subparagraph.text: 55 years old or older; or
Employed in public or approved nonpublic school service for at least 25 years.

paragraph.text: If the program is based on and complies with the standards established by the bylaws, rules, and regulations of the State Board, the State Superintendent shall approve any program of instruction offered by a State institution under the supervision of:

subparagraph.text: The Department of Juvenile Services;
The Developmental Disabilities Administration or Mental Hygiene Administration of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene;
The Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services; or
The residential school located within the Institute of Psychiatry and Human Behavior of the University Hospital.

paragraph.text: If the State Superintendent grants approval, he shall issue a certificate of approval for the program to the institution that offers the program.
The certificate may be revoked for cause by the State Superintendent.
Each institution that offers an approved program shall:

subparagraph.text: Be open at all reasonable times for inspection of the program by the State Superintendent or his designated agent; and
Furnish the information and reports that the State Superintendent considers necessary for evaluation of the program.

paragraph.text: The State Superintendent shall issue a certificate of completion of credit to a resident of an institution who successfully completes an approved program of instruction.

The State Superintendent may furnish visual and auditory aids, educational television, and any other aids to facilitate instruction in all subjects in any school, institution, or organization under the supervision of the State Board.
Material collected for this purpose may be made available for a limited time to any responsible institution or organization for the benefit of citizens of this State.
The State Superintendent may make contracts to carry out the provisions of this subsection.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent shall establish an Early Childhood Development Division within the Department.
The State Superintendent shall perform any other duties assigned to him:

paragraph.text: Under this article; or
By the State Board.

subsection.text: In this section, “noncollegiate educational institution” means a school or other institution that offers an educational program but is not an institution of postsecondary education, as defined in § 10-101 of this article.

paragraph.text: Before a private noncollegiate educational institution that operates in this State ends operations, including those operated by bona fide church organizations, the chief administrative officer of the institution shall file with the State Superintendent the original or a legible copy of all essential records of the academic achievements of each former student of the institution who received instruction in any combination of grades 9 through 12 or their equivalents.

These records shall be prepared to present as a separate document the academic record of each former student and the academic information that customarily is required by postsecondary educational institutions when considering a student for admission.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent shall keep a permanent file of these records.
Any person who willfully fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 for each violation.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agency” means a local education agency serving a population of students at least 80% of which are minority students.
“Minority student” has the meaning stated in regulations adopted by the State Superintendent.
There is a Lacrosse Opportunities Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Lacrosse Opportunities Program is to increase opportunities for minority students to participate in lacrosse in their communities.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent shall develop and administer the Lacrosse Opportunities Program.

paragraph.text: An agency may submit an application to the Department to receive a grant for a program that is in furtherance of the purpose of the Lacrosse Opportunities Program.
An application shall include:

subparagraph.text: A description of the scope and purpose of the proposed program;
A business plan that includes the estimated total cost of the proposed program; and
Any other information required by the Department.

subsection.text: In awarding a grant under the Lacrosse Opportunities Program, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: Require the grantee to provide matching funds from any combination of federal, county, municipal, or private sources; and
Ensure that the grant does not exceed 50% of the total annual cost of the grantee’s program.

subsection.text: The State Superintendent or the State Superintendent’s designee shall:

paragraph.text: Review grant applications submitted in accordance with subsection (d) of this section; and
To the extent funds are available, provide grants to agencies that meet the requirements for a grant under this section.

subsection.text: For fiscal year 2014 and each fiscal year thereafter, the Governor shall include in the annual budget submission at least $40,000 for the Lacrosse Opportunities Program.
The State Superintendent shall adopt regulations to implement this section.

section.text: This title applies to all county boards including Baltimore City.
The geographical boundary of each county school system is the same as the geographical boundary of the county.
There is a county board of education for each county school system.

subsection.text: Each county board is a body politic and corporate by the name of the Board of Education of ........... County.
A county board:

paragraph.text: Has perpetual existence;
May sue and be sued; and
May have, use, alter, or abandon a common seal.

subsection.text: Subsections (b), (c), and (d) of this section do not apply to a county if the number of members of the county board is regulated by other provisions of this title.
If a county school system has an enrollment of less than 50,000 students, the county board shall have five members, except that:

paragraph.text: The Worcester County Board shall have the number of members provided in subsection (e) of this section;
Any county board that had more than five members on July 1, 1969, shall retain that number of members; and
The Wicomico County Board shall have the number of members provided in subsection (f) of this section.

subsection.text: If a county school system has an enrollment of 50,000 students or more but less than 100,000 students, the county board shall have seven members.
If a county school system has an enrollment of 100,000 students or more, the county board shall have nine members except as provided in § 3-901 of this title for Montgomery County.
The Worcester County Board consists of seven voting members and one nonvoting student member from each public high school in the county.

paragraph.text: The Wicomico County Board consists of seven members.
The term of a member is 5 years.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Governor shall appoint the members of each county board from the residents of that county.
The members of the following county boards of education shall be selected as follows:

subparagraph.text: The Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners in accordance with § 3–108.1 of this subtitle;
The Harford County Board of Education in accordance with § 3–6A–01 of this title;
The Caroline County Board of Education in accordance with § 3–3A–02 of this title;
The Anne Arundel County Board of Education in accordance with § 3–110 of this subtitle; and
The county boards of education in the counties listed in § 3–114 of this subtitle in accordance with the provisions of that section.

paragraph.text: Each member shall be appointed solely because of character and fitness and without regard to political affiliation.
An individual who is subject to the authority of the county board may not be appointed to or serve on the county board.
Each member serves for a term of 5 years beginning July 1 after the member’s appointment and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Governor shall appoint a new member to fill any vacancy on an appointed board for the remainder of that term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Unless otherwise disqualified under this section, a member of a board is eligible for reappointment. However, an individual may not serve for more than 2 consecutive terms.
With the approval of the Governor, the State Superintendent may remove any member of a county board appointed under this section for:

subparagraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Incompetency;
Willful neglect of duty; or
Failure to attend, without good cause, at least half of the scheduled meetings of the board in any one calendar year.

paragraph.text: Before removing a member, the State Superintendent shall send the member a copy of the charges against him and give him an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the member requests a hearing within the 10–day period:

subparagraph.text: The State Superintendent promptly shall hold a hearing, but a hearing may not be set within 10 days after the State Superintendent sends the member a notice of the hearing; and
The member shall have an opportunity to be heard publicly before the State Superintendent in his own defense, in person or by counsel.

paragraph.text: If a member who is removed so requests, the State Superintendent shall file with the clerk of the circuit court for the county from which the member was appointed:

subparagraph.text: A complete statement of all charges made against the member;
The findings of the State Superintendent; and
A complete record of the proceedings.

subsection.text: In this section, “board” means the Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners of the Baltimore City Public School System.
There is a Baltimore City Board of School Commissioners of the Baltimore City Public School System.
The board consists of:

paragraph.text: Nine voting members jointly appointed by the Mayor of Baltimore City and the Governor from a list of qualified individuals submitted to the Mayor and the Governor by the State Board; and
One voting student member appointed as provided in subsection (o) of this section.

subsection.text: Each member of the board shall be a resident of Baltimore City.
To the extent practicable, the membership of the board shall reflect the demographic composition of Baltimore City.

At least four of the voting members shall possess a high level of knowledge and expertise concerning the successful administration of a large business, nonprofit, or governmental entity and shall have served in a high level management position within such an entity.
At least three of the voting members shall possess a high level of knowledge and expertise concerning education.
At least one voting member shall be a parent of a student enrolled in the Baltimore City Public School System as of the date of appointment of the member.

paragraph.text: Among the nine voting members, at least one member shall also possess knowledge or experience in the education of children with disabilities.
The knowledge or experience may be derived from being the parent of a child with a disability.
The term of a voting member is 3 years.
The terms of the voting members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the board on June 1, 1997.
At the end of a term, a voting member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A voting member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the remainder of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A voting member may not serve more than two consecutive full terms.

To the extent practicable, the Governor and the Mayor shall fill any vacancy on the board within 60 days of the date of the vacancy from a list of qualified individuals submitted to the Mayor and the Governor by the State Board.

subsection.text: On the joint approval of the Mayor of Baltimore City and the Governor, a member may be removed only for cause in accordance with § 3–108 of this subtitle.
Each member of the board serves without compensation.
On appointment of the board, the Governor and the Mayor shall jointly select one of the voting members to serve as the chairman of the board who shall serve through June 30, 1999.
Beginning on July 1, 1999 and every 2 years thereafter, from among its voting members the board shall elect a chairman.

paragraph.text: One student member shall be a student enrolled in the Baltimore City Public School System who shall be selected by the Associated Student Congress of Baltimore City.
The term of a student member is 1 year.
A student member may not serve more than two consecutive full terms.
The student member may vote on all matters before the board except those relating to:

subparagraph.text: Personnel;
Capital and operating budgets;
School closings, reopenings, and boundaries;
Collective bargaining decisions;
Student disciplinary matters; and
Appeals to the board as provided under §§ 4–205 and 6–202 of this article.

paragraph.text: The student member may not attend or participate in an executive or special session of the board.

subsection.text: Any action by the board shall require:

paragraph.text: A quorum of a majority of the voting members then serving; and
The affirmative vote of a majority of the voting members then serving.

subsection.text: The Baltimore County Board consists of 12 members who shall be appointed as follows:

paragraph.text: Four from the county at large;
One from each of the seven councilmanic districts in Baltimore County; and
One student member from the county at large.
The student member shall:

subparagraph.text: Be an eleventh or twelfth grade student in the Baltimore County public school system;
Serve for 1 year; and
Advise the board on the thoughts and feelings of students.

paragraph.text: Unless invited to attend by an affirmative vote of a majority of the county board, the student member may not attend an executive session that relates to:

subparagraph.text: Hearings on appeals of special education placements;
Hearings held under § 6–202(a) of this article; or
Collective bargaining.

paragraph.text: As provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, the student member may vote on all matters except those relating to:

subparagraph.text: § 6–202(a) of this article;
Collective bargaining;
Capital and operating budgets; and
School closings, reopenings, and boundaries.

paragraph.text: On a majority vote of the nonstudent members, the board may determine, on a case–by–case basis, whether a matter under consideration is covered by the exclusionary provisions listed in paragraph (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A board member who does not maintain his residential qualification shall be replaced as a member.

If the boundary line of a councilmanic district is changed, the term of an incumbent member of the county board who no longer resides in the councilmanic district because of the change is not affected during this term.
There is a School Shared Space Council in Baltimore County consisting of 12 employees of the county appointed by the County Executive for a term coterminous with that of the board as follows:

paragraph.text: Two from the staff of the county board of education;
Two from the County Executive’s administrative staff, one of whom shall be the Director of Central Services;
One from the Department of Social Services;
One from the Department of Recreation and Parks;
One from the Department of Aging;
One from the Health Department;
One from the county community colleges, subject to the following conditions:

subparagraph.text: Representation shall be determined on a rotating basis by alphabetical order by community college name; and
Each such member shall serve for 1 year;

paragraph.text: One from the Department of Juvenile Services;
One from the county public libraries; and
One from the Department of Planning.

subsection.text: A county employee Council member who does not maintain his employment in the county shall be replaced.
In addition to the county employee members, there shall be eight county citizens selected as members of the Council as follows and with the following duties:

paragraph.text: The county citizen members shall be selected by the County Executive. One member shall be selected from each legislative district of Baltimore County with the approval of the State Senator from that district. Each legislative district representative shall reside in that district;

The initial members selected to represent legislative districts 5, 7, 9, and 11 shall each serve for a 2–year term beginning June 1, 1979, and ending May 31, 1981. Thereafter all members shall be selected to serve 2–year terms. The initial members selected to represent legislative districts 8, 10, 12, and 13 shall each serve for a 1–year term beginning June 1, 1979, and ending May 31, 1980, and thereafter all members shall be selected for 2–year terms;
A citizen member shall be entitled to attend and vote at a Council session where an issue before the Council concerns the school or schools in the citizen member’s respective district; and
When the Council meets to consider countywide issues, all selected citizen members shall be entitled to attend such sessions and vote.

subsection.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: Meet as needed to compile the number of spaces in the public schools of the county that are not filled and to evaluate the feasibility of the utilization of the spaces by the community and county departments; and
Report its findings and recommendations to the county board of education and the County Executive at least twice during the school year.

subsection.text: The County Executive may, by executive order, appoint up to two additional members to the Council from agencies of the county government.

paragraph.text: The Anne Arundel County Board consists of 9 members who shall be appointed as follows:

subparagraph.text: 3 from the county at large;
1 each from legislative districts 30, 31, 32, 33, and that portion of legislative district 21 that lies within Anne Arundel County; and
1 student member.

paragraph.text: Except for the student member, the Governor shall appoint a member of the county board from a list of nominees submitted by the School Board Nominating Commission of Anne Arundel County as provided in subsection (b) of this section.

subparagraph.text: There is a School Board Nominating Commission of Anne Arundel County.
The purpose of the Commission is to select nominees to be recommended to the Governor as qualified candidates for appointment to the Anne Arundel County Board of Education.
The Commission shall hold at least two public hearings on the selection of nominees before recommending to the Governor nominees for appointment to the county board.
The Commission consists of 11 members who shall be appointed in accordance with this paragraph.
The Governor shall appoint five members, one from each legislative district that lies in whole or in part in Anne Arundel County.
The County Executive of Anne Arundel County shall appoint one member from the county at large.
The following organizations shall each appoint one member:

sub-subparagraph.text: The Teachers Association of Anne Arundel County;
The Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Chamber of Commerce;
The Anne Arundel County Council of Parent Teacher Associations;
The Anne Arundel County Community College Board of Trustees; and
The Association of Educational Leaders (AEL).

subparagraph.text: The Governor shall designate as chair of the Commission one of the five members appointed by the Governor under subsection (b)(2)(ii) of this section.
The term of the chair of the Commission is 4 years.
The Governor may reappoint the chair of the Commission for a second term.
The term of a member of the Commission is 4 years.

paragraph.text: The Department of Legislative Services shall provide staff for the Commission.
Beginning January 1, 2008, for each nomination to the county board, the Commission shall submit to the Governor a list of nominees that contains:

subparagraph.text: At least two names for each vacancy; or
If there are fewer than two applicants for a vacancy, the number of names that is equal to the number of applicants for the vacancy.

paragraph.text: Following the appointment of a member of the Anne Arundel County Board of Education by the Governor, a member may serve for the remainder of the member’s term, as provided in § 3–108(c) of this subtitle, subject to the approval or rejection of the registered voters of the county at the next general election.
A member of the county board is eligible for nomination and reappointment for a second consecutive term in accordance with the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section.

subparagraph.text: The approval or rejection of a member of the county board by the registered voters of the county provided for in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph shall be a vote for the member’s retention or removal.

On receipt of the notice required under § 5–301(h) of the Election Law Article, the name of the member of the county board shall be placed on the appropriate ballot and shown, without opposition, and the voters shall vote for or against the member’s retention as a member of the county board.

paragraph.text: If the voters reject the retention of the member, or the vote is tied:

subparagraph.text: The position shall become vacant 10 days after certification of the election returns; and
The member serves until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

paragraph.text: The student member shall:

subparagraph.text: Be a regularly enrolled senior year student of good character and in good standing in an Anne Arundel County public high school;
Be selected in the student’s junior year by a method selected by the Chesapeake Regional Association of Student Councils of Anne Arundel County;

sub-subparagraph.text: Serve a term of 1 year; and
Continue to serve after graduation and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

paragraph.text: If a vacancy in the position of the student member occurs during the term of the student member, the Chesapeake Regional Association of Student Councils shall:

subparagraph.text: Conduct a special election at its next general meeting; and
By utilizing the same method that it used to select the previous student member of the board, select another student member to fill the vacancy.

subsection.text: A board member who does not maintain the residency qualification shall be replaced as a member.

If the boundary line of a legislative district changes, an incumbent member of the county board who, because of the change, no longer resides in the legislative district from which the member was appointed may complete the term.

paragraph.text: The President of the Anne Arundel County Board of Education is entitled to receive $8,000 annually as compensation and, except for the student member, the other board members are entitled to receive $6,000 each annually as compensation.
A student member who completes a full term on the board shall be granted a scholarship of $6,000 to be applied toward the student’s higher education costs.

subsection.text: In the following counties, the members of the county board shall be elected:

paragraph.text: Allegany;
Calvert;
Carroll;
Cecil;
Charles;
Dorchester;
Frederick;
Garrett;
Howard;
Kent;
Prince George’s;
Montgomery;
Queen Anne’s;
St. Mary’s;
Somerset;
Talbot;
Washington; and
Worcester.

subsection.text: In Caroline County, in accordance with Subtitle 3A of this title, the members of the county board shall be a combination of members who are elected and appointed.
In Harford County, in accordance with Subtitle 6A of this title, the members of the county board shall be a combination of members who are elected and appointed.

An individual subject to the authority of the county board may not serve as a member of the county board. At the time of filing a certificate of candidacy for election to a county board, a person shall certify to the local board of supervisors of elections whether or not he is subject to the authority of the county board. The Governor shall not issue a commission of election to a person who has certified affirmatively and who is elected to a county board until the member–elect offers proof that he is no longer subject to the authority of the county board.
The election of the county boards shall be held as provided in Subtitles 2 through 14 of this title and the Election Law Article.

paragraph.text: In this subtitle, “elected member” means a voting member elected under subsection (d) or (e) of this section or a member appointed to an elected position on the county board under subsection (e)(3) of this section.
“Elected member” does not include a:

subparagraph.text: County Commissioner serving as an ex officio member of the county board; or
Nonvoting student member selected under subsection (f) of this section.

subsection.text: The Allegany County Board consists of:

paragraph.text: Five elected members;
The Chairman of the Board of County Commissioners, or any County Commissioner so designated by the Chairman, who is an ex officio nonvoting member; and
One nonvoting student member, who is to advise the other members of the county board on the viewpoint of students who attend Allegany County public schools.

subsection.text: An individual nominated for membership as an elected member on the county board shall be a qualified voter and a resident of Allegany County for at least 1 year before the election.
The elected members of the Allegany County Board shall be elected:

paragraph.text: At a general election as required by this subsection or as provided under subsection (e) of this section; and
From Allegany County at large.

Each elected member serves for a term of 4 years beginning on January 2 after the member’s election and until a successor is elected and qualifies. If January 2 is a legal holiday, the term begins on the first day after January 2 that is not a legal holiday.
The terms of elected members are staggered as required by the terms of the members serving on the county board on July 1, 1978.

Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, the Governor shall appoint a new member to fill any vacancy of an elected member’s position on the board for the remainder of that term and until a successor is elected and qualifies.

If a vacancy occurs before the date that is 10 days prior to the filing deadline for candidates for the primary election that is held in the second year of the term, the individual appointed under paragraph (3) of this subsection shall serve only until a successor is elected by the voters at the time of the next general election.
Candidates for the vacated office may be nominated at a primary election in the same manner as for any other position on the county board.

When more than one member of the board is to be elected at an election and the terms of the offices to be filled at the election vary, the elected candidate receiving the greater number of votes shall fill the office with the longer term.

The candidate receiving the vacated position shall take office as soon as possible after the election, and shall continue to serve for the remainder of the vacated term and until a successor is elected and qualifies.
Except as provided in this subsection, an election to fill a vacancy on the Allegany County Board of Education shall be governed by §§ 8–801 through 8–806 of the Election Law Article.
The Allegany County Board of Supervisors of Elections may adopt regulations to implement this subsection.
The nonvoting student member of the county board shall be:

subparagraph.text: A twelfth grade student, in good standing, and regularly enrolled in an Allegany County public school;
A resident of Allegany County for at least 2 years; and
Of good character.

paragraph.text: The nonvoting student member shall be nominated and elected for a 1–year term during the school year prior to the school year that the member is to serve on the county board in accordance with procedures adopted by the Allegany County Association of Student Councils.

If a vacancy occurs in the student member’s position before the end of the term, a qualified student shall be selected for the remainder of the term in accordance with procedures of the Allegany County Association of Student Councils.
The State Board may remove an elected member of the county board for:

subparagraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Incompetency; or
Willful neglect of duty.

paragraph.text: Before removing a member, the State Board shall send the member a copy of the charges and give the member an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the member requests a hearing within the 10–day period:

subparagraph.text: The State Board promptly shall hold a hearing, but a hearing may not be set within 10 days after the State Board sends the member a notice of the hearing; and
The member shall have an opportunity to be heard publicly before the State Board in the member’s own defense, in person or by counsel.

paragraph.text: A member removed under this subsection has the right to a de novo review of the removal by the Circuit Court for Allegany County.

section.text: The county board from time to time shall elect a president and vice president from among its elected members.

paragraph.text: Except for the ex officio member, each elected county board member is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: An annual salary set by the Allegany County Commissioners in accordance with Article 24, Title 12, Subtitle 1 of the Code; and
Reimbursement, after submitting vouchers, for travel and other expenses.

paragraph.text: Except for the ex officio member, each elected member of the county board shall be paid in 12 equal monthly installments.

subsection.text: The Chairman of the Board of County Commissioners serves on the county board without additional compensation. However, after submitting vouchers, the Chairman or the Chairman’s designee is entitled to reimbursement for travel and other expenses incurred as a result of meetings of the board.
All actions of the county board shall be taken at a public meeting and a record of the meeting and all actions shall be made public.

This section does not prohibit the county board from meeting and deliberating in executive session, provided that any action of the board, together with the individual vote of each member, is contained in a public record.
A nonvoting student member may not attend executive sessions of the county board.
The Calvert County Board consists of five voting members and one nonvoting student member.
The five voting members of the Calvert County Board shall be elected at a general election as required by subsections (d) and (f) of this section.

subparagraph.text: A member from a county commissioner district shall be a resident of the district.
A member from a county commissioner district who no longer resides in the district may not continue as a member of the county board.
A member from the county at large shall be a resident of the county.
A member at large who no longer resides in the county may not continue as a member of the county board.

paragraph.text: A member of the county board shall be a registered voter of the county for at least 2 years prior to the date of the beginning of the term of office of the member.

subsection.text: Of the five voting members of the county board:

paragraph.text: One shall be elected from each of the three county commissioner districts; and
Two shall be elected from the county at large.
Except for the student member, a member serves for a term of 4 years beginning January 1 after the election of the member and until a successor is elected and qualifies.
The County Commissioners shall appoint a new member to fill any vacancy on the county board for the remainder of that term and until a successor is elected and qualifies.

subparagraph.text: Unless otherwise disqualified under this section, a member of the county board is eligible for reelection.
An individual may not serve for more than three consecutive terms.

paragraph.text: One member shall be elected from each of the county commissioner districts at the November, 1996 general election.
Two members shall be elected from the county at large at the November, 1996 general election.
The terms of members are staggered as provided in subsection (i) of this section.
The terms of the interim incumbent members of the county board who hold office on October 1, 1995 shall expire on January 1, 1997.
The members elected under the provisions of subsection (f) of this section shall be elected to replace the members of the county board serving on the board on the date of the election.
The student member shall:

subparagraph.text: Be an eleventh or twelfth grade student in the Calvert County public school system elected by the high school students of the county in accordance with procedures established by the school system;
Serve for 1 year beginning on June 1;
Be a nonvoting member; and
Advise the board on the thoughts and feelings of the students.

paragraph.text: Unless invited to attend by an affirmative vote of a majority of the county board, the student may not attend an executive session.

subsection.text: The terms of the members of the county board who take office on January 1, 1997 shall expire as follows:

paragraph.text: The members elected from each of the county commissioner districts in 2000; and
The members elected from the county at large in 2002.

subsection.text: The State Board may remove a member of the county board for any of the following reasons:

paragraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Incompetency;
Willful neglect of duty; or
Failure to attend, without good cause, at least 75 percent of the scheduled meetings of the board in any 1 calendar year.

subsection.text: Before removing a member, the State Board shall send the member a copy of the charges against the member and give the member an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the member requests a hearing within the 10–day period:

paragraph.text: The State Board shall promptly hold a hearing, but a hearing may not be set within 10 days after the State Board sends the member a notice of the hearing; and
The member shall have an opportunity to be heard publicly before the State Board in the member’s own defense, in person, or by counsel.

subsection.text: A member removed under this section has the right to a de novo review of the removal by the Circuit Court for Calvert County.
At its first meeting at the beginning of each calendar year, the county board shall elect a president and a vice president from among its members.

paragraph.text: The president of the county board is entitled to receive $6,500 annually as compensation and the other members are entitled to receive $5,500 each annually as compensation.

An elected member is entitled to health insurance benefits regularly provided to employees of the board of education under the same terms and conditions extended to other employees of the board of education.

subsection.text: The county board shall meet at least once each month.

Except for those actions authorized by subsection (c) of this section, all actions of the county board shall be taken at a public meeting and a record of the meeting and all actions shall be made public.
The county board may take actions in closed session in accordance with § 10–508 of the State Government Article.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Appointed member” means one of the two voting members appointed by the Governor, with the advice and consent of the Senate, under § 3–3A–02(b)(3)(i)1 of this subtitle.
“Board of education district” or “district” means a geographic area of Caroline County in which an elected member of the Caroline County Board of Education must be a legal resident.

paragraph.text: “Elected member” means one of the three nonpartisan voting members of the Caroline County Board of Education elected by the voters of Caroline County.
“Elected member” does not include the nonvoting student members selected under § 3–3A–02(f) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Caroline County Board of Education consists of:

paragraph.text: Three elected members;
Two appointed members; and
Two nonvoting student members.
One elected member shall be elected from each of the three board of education districts established in Caroline County.
An elected member shall be:

subparagraph.text: A resident of the district from which the member is elected; and
Elected only by the voters of that district.

sub-subparagraph.text: Two appointed members shall be appointed by the Governor, with the advice and consent of the Senate, from the county at–large.
Each appointed member shall be a resident of the county.

subparagraph.text: In appointing members to the county board, the Governor shall ensure, to the extent practicable, that the total makeup of the county board reflects gender, ethnic, and racial diversity.

paragraph.text: The board of education districts shall:

subparagraph.text: Be established by the County Commissioners of Caroline County; and
Be substantially equal in population and reapportioned on the basis of each decennial census of the United States.

paragraph.text: Reapportioned districts shall become effective for the term of office commencing after the first regular primary election held at least 15 months after the official report on population is received by the State from the Bureau of the Census.
As applicable for that board of education district, at the general election the ballot shall provide the voter with the choice to cast a vote “For” a candidate for election from that district.
After the election results are certified, the State Board of Elections shall declare for each district whether a candidate has been elected.
An individual elected to the county board shall be at least 21 years old and a registered voter and resident of Caroline County for at least 3 years.
A member may not continue as a member of the county board if the member:

subparagraph.text: No longer resides in the board of education district that the member is designated to represent; or
Is not a registered voter of Caroline County.

paragraph.text: An individual employed by, or under the direction of, the county board or the Caroline County Superintendent of Schools is not eligible to serve on the county board.
A student member of the county board shall:

subparagraph.text: Be a regularly enrolled eleventh or twelfth grade student of good character and in good standing in a Caroline County public high school during the student’s term in office;
Be selected in the student’s tenth or eleventh grade in accordance with paragraph (3) of this subsection; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Serve for a term of 1 year; and
If the student is in the twelfth grade, continue to serve after graduation and until a successor is selected and qualifies.

paragraph.text: Each high school in the county shall be represented by a student member of the county board.

subparagraph.text: For nomination to the county board, the student body shall submit to the principal of the high school a list of nominees that contains the names of eligible students.
The principal of the high school shall select the student member from the list of nominees submitted to the principal under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: If a vacancy in the position of student member occurs during the term of a student member, the principal of the high school represented on the county board shall select another student member using the method set forth under paragraph (3) of this subsection.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, each elected member serves for a term of 4 years beginning on the first Monday in December after the member’s election and until a successor is elected and qualifies.
The initial terms of the elected members are staggered as follows:

subparagraph.text: The two members elected to the county board at the general election in November 2012 who receive the highest number of votes cast from among the successful candidates at that election shall serve for a term of 4 years; and

The member elected to the county board at the general election in November 2012 who receives the least number of votes cast from among the successful candidates at that election shall serve for a term of 2 years.

paragraph.text: In the event of a vacancy of an elected member on the county board due to death, resignation, disqualification, or removal, the remaining voting members shall select a qualified individual to fill the vacancy for the remainder of the term of the vacating member and until a successor is elected and qualifies.
An individual appointed to fill a vacancy for an elected member shall be a resident of the same board of education district as that of the vacating member.
Before filling a vacancy for an elected member, the remaining voting members of the county board shall conduct an interview of each applicant at an open meeting.

subparagraph.text: The county board shall publish a list of the names of the applicants for a vacancy on the county board at least 2 weeks before the interview of the first applicant is scheduled to occur.
The county board shall cause public notice of the date, time, and location of the interview for each applicant to be published:

sub-subparagraph.text: At least 2 weeks before the interview is scheduled to occur; and
In the same manner as public notice of a regular meeting of the county board is published.

paragraph.text: The county board is not required to conduct discussions of the applicants or make the final selection of the elected member to fill the vacancy at an open meeting.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, each appointed member serves for a term of 4 years beginning on the first Monday in December 2012.
The initial terms of the appointed members are staggered as follows:

subparagraph.text: One appointed member shall serve for a term of 6 years; and
One appointed member shall serve for a term of 4 years.

paragraph.text: In the event of a vacancy of an appointed member due to death, resignation, disqualification, or removal, the Governor shall appoint another individual to complete the term of the vacating appointed member.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the State Board may remove any member of the county board for any of the following reasons:

paragraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Incompetency; or
Willful neglect of duty.

subsection.text: Before removing a member, the State Board shall send the member a copy of the charges against the member and give the member an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the member requests a hearing within the 10–day period:

subparagraph.text: The State Board promptly shall hold a hearing; but
A hearing may not be set within 10 days after the State Board sends the member a notice of the hearing; and

paragraph.text: The member shall have an opportunity to be heard publicly before the State Board in the member’s own defense, in person or by counsel.

subsection.text: A member removed under this section has the right to a de novo review of the removal by the Circuit Court for Caroline County.
At its first meeting in December of each year, the voting members of the county board shall elect a president and vice president from among its members.

In the event of a vacancy in the office of president or vice president of the county board, the voting members of the county board shall elect a new officer to fill the vacancy within 30 days after the vacancy occurs.
The president of the county board is entitled to receive $4,000 annually as compensation, and the other voting members are entitled to receive $3,500 each annually as compensation.
As provided in the Caroline County budget, each voting member is entitled to an allowance for travel and other expenses.

A voting member is not eligible for any fringe benefit provided by the Caroline County Public School System, the Caroline County Board of Education, or the County Commissioners of Caroline County, including:

paragraph.text: Health insurance;
Life insurance; and
A pension.

subsection.text: The county board shall meet at least once each month.

paragraph.text: Each meeting of the county board shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Open Meetings Act, Title 10, Subtitle 5 of the State Government Article.
The county board may avail itself of any exclusion authorized under the Maryland Open Meetings Act.

subsection.text: The Carroll County Board consists of:

paragraph.text: Five voting members; and
The County Commissioners, who are nonvoting ex officio members.

subsection.text: A candidate elected to the county board shall be a resident and registered voter of Carroll County. Any member who no longer resides in Carroll County may not continue as a member of the board.

paragraph.text: Members of the Carroll County Board shall be elected as follows:

subparagraph.text: Two members of the board shall be elected in the November general election of 1994 and every 4 years thereafter;
Two members of the county board shall be elected in the November general election of 1996 and every 4 years thereafter; and
One member of the county board shall be elected in the November general election of 1998 and every 4 years thereafter.

paragraph.text: Members of the county board shall be elected:

subparagraph.text: At a general election as required by this section; and
On a general countywide ticket.

paragraph.text: Each member serves for a term of 4 years beginning the first Monday in December immediately following the member’s election and until a successor is elected and qualifies. The terms of the members are staggered as required for the elections to the county board in subsection (c)(1) of this section.
The Governor shall appoint a new member to fill any vacancy on the board for the remainder of that term and until a successor is elected and qualifies.

A member of the county board as of October 1, 1993, and any member appointed to fill a vacancy in an unexpired term of such member, shall hold office during his term and until a successor is elected and qualifies.
The State Board may remove a member of the county board for:

subparagraph.text: Immorality;
Misconduct in office;
Incompetency; or
Willful neglect of duty.

paragraph.text: Before removing a member, the State Board shall send the member a copy of the charges against him and give him an opportunity within 10 days to request a hearing.
If the member requests a hearing within the 10–day period:
