Subject to subsection (c) of this section, have an annual family income below a poverty index determined by the Commission; and
Satisfy any additional criteria the Commission may establish.

subsection.text: To determine the annual family income eligibility of an applicant for a Guaranteed Access Grant, the Office may not consider an amount received by the applicant as an earned income credit under § 32 of the Internal Revenue Code.

A student in grade 9 or grade 10 who applies and qualifies for a Guaranteed Access Grant on the basis of financial need as established by the Commission shall prequalify for a Guaranteed Access Grant to be used at the time of enrollment in an institution of higher education by agreeing in writing, as a secondary and undergraduate student, to:

paragraph.text: Satisfy the attendance policy of the applicable school;
Refrain from substance abuse;
Provide information required by the Commission or the State Board of Education;
Complete and file on a timely basis applications for federal student aid for each year that the student plans to enroll in postsecondary education;

Participate in the College Readiness Outreach Program established in § 18–303.1 of this subtitle until the student graduates from high school and matriculates at an institution of higher education; and
Satisfy any other program requirements set by the Office, the Commission, the State Board of Education, or the State Department of Education.

subsection.text: In this section, “Program” means the College Readiness Outreach Program.

The Commission and the Department, in collaboration with county boards of education, county superintendents, and institutions of higher education, shall jointly administer the College Readiness Outreach Program.
The Program shall provide guidance to students who qualify for a Guaranteed Access Grant in 9th or 10th grade to assist the students in successfully:

paragraph.text: Completing a college preparatory curriculum;
Graduating from high school; and
Matriculating at an institution of higher education as defined in §§ 18-305 and 18-308 of this subtitle.
The Commission and the Department shall designate statewide and regional coordinators for the Program.
The statewide and regional coordinators shall:

subparagraph.text: Work with county boards of education and county superintendents to provide guidance and one-on-one mentoring to participating students in high school; and
Publicize the Program through community outreach and marketing materials.

subsection.text: The Commission and the Department may enter into agreements with existing organizations that provide counseling and mentoring services to fulfill the requirements of this section.
The Commission and the Department may supplement professional mentors with:

paragraph.text: Postsecondary students receiving work-study assistance at Maryland institutions of higher education; and
Secondary students in 11th and 12th grades who are successfully completing high school graduation requirements.
Funds for the Program shall be as provided in the State budget.

To the extent that funds are provided, the State shall provide 50 percent of the costs associated with the local administration and one–on–one mentoring components of the Program, except that in a county that meets the requirements of a “qualified distressed county” under § 1–101 of the Economic Development Article the State shall provide 75 percent of the costs.

subsection.text: The Commission and the Department may adopt regulations necessary to implement this section.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in § 18–307 of this subtitle, the Office shall determine the amount of each Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award based on the financial need of the applicant.
In determining the amount of financial need, the Office shall consider regional cost–of–living differences.

In determining the percent of financial need used to calculate an award for a community college student receiving a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award, the Commission shall use the following percentages:

subparagraph.text: For fiscal year 2007, not less than 55%; and
For fiscal year 2008 and each fiscal year thereafter, not less than 60%.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award may be awarded in $100 increments and the award for a single year may not be less than $400 or more than $3,000.

subparagraph.text: All applicants who fulfill the requirements established in § 18–303(a) and (b) of this subtitle shall receive a Guaranteed Access Grant.

The amount of a Guaranteed Access Grant shall be equal to 100 percent of the student’s financial need as determined by the Office, not to exceed the equivalent annual expenses of a full–time resident undergraduate at the 4–year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full–time resident undergraduate.

subsection.text: A Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award may be used:

paragraph.text: At a degree granting institution of higher education, an eligible institution with an associate degree program that provides transfer credit for an accredited baccalaureate program, or a hospital diploma school for training registered nurses if the curriculum is approved by the Commission; and
For educational expenses as defined by the Commission, including:

subparagraph.text: Tuition and fees; and
Room and board.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award may be used at a school in another state if:

paragraph.text: There is a reciprocal agreement as provided in § 18–308 of this subtitle; and
The school meets requirements of subsection (a)(1) of this section.

subsection.text: The Office may not award more than 10% of the funds available for each of the types of grants awarded under this subtitle for use by students attending schools in another state.
Subject to the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, each recipient of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award may hold the award for 5 years if the recipient:

paragraph.text: Continues to be a resident of this State;
Continues to be a full–time student at an eligible institution and takes at least 12 semester hours of courses each semester, or its equivalent as determined by the Office;
In the judgment of the institution, is making satisfactory progress toward a degree; and
Maintains the standards of the institution.

subsection.text: Each recipient of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award who is enrolled in an associate degree program as permitted in § 18–303(a)(1) of this subtitle may hold the award for 3 years if the same conditions of subsection (a) of this section are met.
Each recipient of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award may hold the award for a 5th year if the recipient:

paragraph.text: Is enrolled in an academic program that, as determined by the institution, requires 5 years to complete; or
Provides evidence, satisfactory to the Office, of extenuating financial, academic, or other circumstances that prevent the recipient from completing the academic program in 4 years.

subsection.text: In addition to the requirements for renewal of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award under subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section, a recipient of a Guaranteed Access Grant shall hold the grant for not more than 5 consecutive years or, failing to do so, provide evidence satisfactory to the Office of extenuating circumstances.
Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, the Office shall compile and certify lists for the entire State that rank applicants by financial need.
All funds for annual initial grants shall be awarded from the statewide list on the basis of greatest financial need.

On or before May 1 of each year, the Office shall send each Senator and each Delegate a list of individuals in each legislative district to whom Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Awards are awarded.

subparagraph.text: If State funds are available for this purpose, institutions of higher education in the State may provide Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Awards to students who otherwise meet the requirements for receiving a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award but who apply after the March 1 deadline or have other extenuating circumstances.
Each year the Commission shall transfer at least $2 million of the funds available under § 18–107(b) of this title for the purposes of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: Establish guidelines for the awarding of Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Awards by the institutions of higher education to the students; and
Adopt regulations necessary for the implementation of this subsection.
The Commission shall allocate available funds to institutions of higher education based on the proportion of State residents enrolled at each institution who receive federal Pell Grants.
An institution of higher education that receives funds under this paragraph shall provide the Commission with an annual audit describing the disposition of the funds.

subsection.text: In this section, “school” means an institution that meets the requirements of § 18–305(a)(1) of this subtitle.
The Office may enter into reciprocal scholarship agreements with other states. However, the Office shall give priority to entering into reciprocal agreements with contiguous and nearby states.

If scholarships are awarded to students for use in schools in other states, the total value of all of these awards may not be more than 10 percent of the total funds budgeted for the Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award Program.

For any fiscal year, if the funds appropriated for the Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award Program are insufficient to satisfy fully all awards as calculated under § 18–304 of this subtitle, the amount paid to each recipient of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award shall be a percentage of that award, as determined in accordance with regulations adopted by the Commission that establish a schedule of reductions for this purpose.

paragraph.text: Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award grants calculated under § 18–304 of this subtitle that are not used by the recipients shall be retained by the Commission for use in the Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award Program for the next fiscal year.

All funds retained in the Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award Program as provided in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be used to award scholarships to students during subsequent fiscal years as provided by this title and may not be used for administrative expenses.

subsection.text: Funds for the Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award Program shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.

paragraph.text: There is an Educational Excellence Fund in the Commission.
The Commission:

subparagraph.text: May accept any gift or grant from any person or corporation for the Educational Excellence Fund;

Shall use any gift or grant that it receives to support an early intervention program to identify students eligible for the Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award Program and prepare them for college; and
Shall deposit any gift or grant that it receives for the Fund with the State Treasurer in a nonbudgeted account for use only in the early intervention program.

At the end of the fiscal year, the Commission shall prepare an annual report on the Educational Excellence Fund that includes an accounting of all financial receipts and expenditures to and from the Fund.
The Commission shall submit a copy of the report to the General Assembly as provided under § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.

section.text: There is a program of senatorial scholarships in this State that are awarded under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each applicant for a senatorial scholarship shall:

subparagraph.text: Take a competitive examination administered by the Office; and

Be accepted for admission in the regular undergraduate, graduate, or professional program at an eligible institution; or be enrolled in a 2-year terminal certificate program in which the course work is acceptable for transfer credit for an accredited baccalaureate program in an eligible institution.

paragraph.text: An applicant is exempt from the examination if the applicant:

subparagraph.text: Is attending an eligible institution and has completed at least 1 year in good academic standing at the institution;
Graduated from high school at least 5 years before application for a senatorial scholarship;

Is accepted for admission to a private career institution, if the institution’s curriculum is approved by the Commission, and the institution is accredited by a national accrediting association approved by the United States Department of Education; or
Is planning to attend or is attending a Maryland community college.

subsection.text: Each applicant shall:

paragraph.text: Be a resident of this State; and
At the time of the applicant’s initial application, be a resident of the legislative district from which the applicant seeks an award.
Each applicant shall demonstrate to the Office a definite financial need, and each Senator shall consider the financial need of each applicant.
Each Senator is the final judge of the financial need of each applicant to whom he awards a scholarship, and the Office may not negate this judgment or impose requirements of time or procedure.

subsection.text: Each applicant shall accept any other conditions attached to the award.

section.text: If a Senator serves from a legislative district composed of more than one county, the number of scholarship units shall be divided as equally as possible among qualified applicants from each county in the legislative district.

subsection.text: Each Senator may award $34,500 of senatorial scholarships each year.

paragraph.text: The annual allocation under subsection (a) of this section applies to initial–year awards. After 4 years of operation, the annual allocation to each Senator for initial–year and continuing awards may not exceed four times the amount of his allocation under subsection (a) of this section.
If a recipient moves to the legislative district of another Senator, the allocation to the recipient shall continue to be drawn on the account of the Senator who originally awarded the scholarship.
A senatorial scholarship may be awarded in $100 increments.

An award for a single year may not be less than $400 or more than the equivalent annual tuition and mandatory fees of an undergraduate program at the 4–year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full–time resident undergraduate.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, a senatorial scholarship may be used only at any undergraduate, graduate, or professional school in the State.
A senatorial scholarship may be used:

paragraph.text: If the curriculum is approved by the Commission, at a degree granting institution of higher education, a hospital diploma school for training registered nurses, or to attend a private postsecondary proprietary institution that is accredited by a national accrediting association approved by the United States Department of Education as a full-time student; and
For educational expenses as defined by the Office, including:

subparagraph.text: Tuition and mandatory fees; and
Room and board.

subsection.text: If on-campus housing is available, a senatorial scholarship may not be used to pay for off-campus housing.

Each Senator may award not more than 10 percent of the funds available under this subtitle to applicants planning to attend accredited undergraduate, graduate, or professional institutions outside the State, provided the applicant:

paragraph.text: Will be studying in an academic area that is not available in the State; or

Is a hearing impaired person who will be studying at an institution outside the State that makes special provisions for hearing impaired students, and comparable special provisions are not available to that student at an institution in the State.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, each recipient of a senatorial scholarship may hold the scholarship for 4 undergraduate academic years and 4 graduate academic years if he:

paragraph.text: Is a full-time student;
Continues to be a resident of this State; and

Continues to be a student at the institution and takes at least 12 semester hours of courses as an undergraduate or 9 semester hours of courses as a graduate student each semester leading to a degree.

subsection.text: A recipient of an undergraduate or graduate senatorial scholarship may hold the scholarship, appropriately prorated, for 8 academic years if he:

paragraph.text: Is a part-time student;
Continues to be a resident of this State; and
Continues to be a student at the institution and takes at least 6 semester hours of courses each semester leading to a degree.

subsection.text: Any recipient of a senatorial scholarship may use up to one–half of the yearly award for summer school.

A recipient of a senatorial scholarship who is enrolled in a terminal certificate program as provided in § 18-402(a) of this subtitle may hold the scholarship for 2 years if he is a full-time student and otherwise meets the conditions of subsection (a) of this section, or may hold the scholarship for 4 years if he is a part-time student and otherwise meets the conditions of subsection (b) of this section.

Each recipient of a senatorial scholarship who is enrolled in a private postsecondary proprietary institution that is accredited by a national accrediting association approved by the United States Department of Education:

paragraph.text: May hold the scholarship for the completion of 1 program if the student otherwise meets the conditions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of subsection (a) of this section; and
Shall complete the program within the length of time prescribed by the institution for the completion of the program.

subsection.text: Each Senator shall award all of his senatorial scholarships on or before September 1 of each year.
If any Senator fails to award all of his scholarships on or before September 1 of each year, the Commission shall make the remaining awards to applicants from the Senator’s legislative district who:

paragraph.text: Scored highest on the competitive examination; or
Are attending an eligible institution and have completed at least 1 year in good academic standing.

subsection.text: The Office shall:

paragraph.text: Notify each Senator of the applicants to whom it awards the Senator’s scholarships; and
Announce publicly the names of all recipients.

subsection.text: To the extent a scholarship awarded under § 18-404 of this subtitle is not used by a student, moneys appropriated to the Commission for that award not used by the end of the fiscal year shall be retained by the Commission for use by the awarding Senator in the Senatorial Scholarship Program during subsequent fiscal years.
If there is no qualified applicant in a legislative district, a qualified applicant who resides in another legislative district may be appointed to receive the senatorial scholarship.

A senatorial scholarship awarded under this section is for 1 year. However, a student who receives an appointment under this section is eligible to receive a subsequent appointment for not longer than 3 years.
There is a program of Delegate Scholarships in this State that are awarded under this subtitle.
A scholarship awarded under this subtitle may be used at:

paragraph.text: An eligible institution for a program of undergraduate, graduate, or professional studies;
An accredited undergraduate, graduate, or professional institution outside the State, if:

subparagraph.text: The applicant will be studying in an academic area that is not available in this State; or

sub-subparagraph.text: The applicant is disabled;
The applicant will be studying at an institution outside the State that makes special provisions for disabled students; and
Comparable special provisions are not available to that student at an institution in the State; and

paragraph.text: A private career school within the State that is approved by the Maryland Higher Education Commission under § 11-202 of this article and that is accredited by a national accrediting association that is approved by the United States Department of Education.

subsection.text: Moneys appropriated to the Commission for scholarships awarded under this section that are not used by the end of the fiscal year shall be retained by the Commission for use by the awarding Delegate in the Delegate Scholarship Program during subsequent fiscal years.

section.text: Each member of the House of Delegates may select the recipients of the scholarships on any basis that the Delegate considers appropriate.

subsection.text: During each term in office, each Delegate may award the equivalent of four 4-year full-time scholarships, which may be awarded for either 1-, 2-, 3-, or 4-year periods.

paragraph.text: Each scholarship pays the tuition and mandatory fees at any eligible institution.

The annual amount of a scholarship at a private institution or any graduate or professional program may not exceed the equivalent annual tuition and mandatory fees of an undergraduate program at the 4-year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full-time resident undergraduate.

subsection.text: A Delegate may award two part–time scholarships for each full–time scholarship available.
A part–time scholarship may not be for more than twice as many years as a full–time scholarship.
Each recipient of a part–time scholarship shall carry at least 6 semester hours of courses each semester in a program leading to a degree.
Each recipient of a full-time Delegate Scholarship may use the scholarship to attend summer school.
The term of a full-time Delegate Scholarship shall be shortened by one-half year for each summer of use.
The amount used for summer school may not exceed one-half of the value of the award for the next academic year.

As an alternative to the scholarship awards authorized by §§ 18–503 through 18–505 of this subtitle, and subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, during each year in office each Delegate may award scholarships in a total amount equal to four times the tuition and mandatory fees for a full–time undergraduate student enrolled at the University of Maryland, College Park for the academic year commencing in that year.
A scholarship award under subsection (a) of this section:

paragraph.text: May not be for an amount less than $200 or more than one–half of the total amount of scholarships authorized by subsection (a) of this section for that year;
Shall be used at an eligible institution;
May be used by:

subparagraph.text: A graduate, undergraduate, or professional student; or

A student at a private career school within the State that is approved by the Maryland Higher Education Commission under § 11–202 of this article and that is accredited by a national accrediting association that is approved by the United States Department of Education; and

paragraph.text: To the extent it is not used by the student, shall be recredited to the Delegate’s scholarship account and may be awarded in the next 12 months by that Delegate to another student pursuant to this section.

subsection.text: Beginning in fiscal year 1996, each Delegate may authorize the Office of Student Financial Assistance to award all or a portion of the funds authorized under this subtitle to eligible recipients of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award who reside in the Delegate’s legislative district.

In the event that the total number of eligible recipients of a Delegate Howard P. Rawlings Educational Excellence Award who reside in the Delegate’s legislative district is insufficient to utilize the total amount of funds available to the Delegate for any fiscal year, the Office of Student Financial Assistance may, with the consent of the Delegate, award the unused funds to other eligible recipients throughout the State.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Disabled public safety employee” means a State or local public safety employee who sustains an injury in the line of duty that:

subparagraph.text: Precludes the individual from continuing to serve or be employed as a State or local public safety employee; and

In the case of a volunteer member of a fire department or ambulance or rescue company or squad, precludes the member from continuing to be employed in the nonpublic safety occupation in which the member is engaged at the time of the injury.

paragraph.text: “Surviving spouse” means a person who has not remarried.
“State or local public safety employee” means a person who is:

subparagraph.text: A career or volunteer member of a:

sub-subparagraph.text: Fire department;
Ambulance company or squad; or
Rescue company or squad;

subparagraph.text: A law enforcement officer;
A correctional officer; or
A member of the Maryland National Guard who was a resident of this State at the time of death.

paragraph.text: “Victim of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks” means a Maryland resident who was killed as a result of the attacks on the World Trade Center in New York City, the attack on the Pentagon in Virginia, or the crash of United Airlines Flight 93 in Pennsylvania.

subsection.text: There is a program of scholarships that are awarded by eligible postsecondary institutions under this section.
The Program is the Edward T. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program.
A person may apply to an eligible postsecondary institution for a scholarship under this section if the person:

subparagraph.text: Is a resident of Maryland at the time of application; or
Was a resident of Maryland when an event described in paragraph (3) of this subsection occurred;
Is accepted for admission or enrolled in the regular undergraduate, graduate or professional program at an eligible institution; or
Is enrolled in a 2–year terminal certificate program in which the course work is acceptable for transfer credit for an accredited baccalaureate program in an eligible institution; and
Is at least 16 years old and a son or daughter of a member of the armed forces who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Died as a result of military service after December 7, 1941;
Suffered a service connected 100% permanent disability after December 7, 1941; or

Was declared to be a prisoner of war or missing in action, if that occurred on or after January 1, 1960, as a result of the Vietnam conflict, and if the child was born prior to or while the parent was a prisoner of war or missing in action;

subparagraph.text: Was a prisoner of war or missing in action, if that occurred on or after January 1, 1960, as a result of the Vietnam conflict and was a resident of this State at the time the person was declared to be a prisoner of war or missing in action;

sub-subparagraph.text: Is at least 16 years old and a son or daughter of any State or local public safety employee killed in the line of duty; or
Is the surviving spouse of any State or local public safety employee killed in the line of duty;
Is a disabled public safety employee;
Is at least 16 years old and a son or daughter of a disabled public safety employee who sustains an injury in the line of duty that renders the public safety employee 100% disabled; or
Is the surviving spouse of a disabled public safety employee who sustains an injury in the line of duty that renders the public safety employee 100% disabled;

subparagraph.text: Is a veteran, as defined under § 9–901 of the State Government Article, who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Suffers a service connected disability of 25% or greater; and
Has exhausted or is no longer eligible for federal veterans’ educational benefits;

subparagraph.text: Is the surviving spouse of a member of the armed forces who suffered a service connected 100% permanent disability; or
Is at least 16 years old and a son or daughter of or the surviving spouse of a victim of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

subsection.text: A scholarship awarded under this section:

paragraph.text: May be used for the tuition and mandatory fees at any eligible institution; and
May not:

subparagraph.text: Exceed the equivalent annual tuition and mandatory fees of a resident undergraduate student at the 4–year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full–time resident undergraduate; and
Be less than the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: The equivalent annual tuition and mandatory fees of a resident of the institution attended by the recipient of the scholarship.

paragraph.text: Each postsecondary institution shall determine the eligibility of persons who apply to the institution for the Edward T. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program.

Funds for the Edward T. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program shall be allocated by the Commission to each postsecondary institution based on the number of eligible recipients attending each institution.
In October and February of each year, each postsecondary institution shall report to the Commission the number of eligible recipients attending the institution.
The Commission shall allocate funds for awards to postsecondary institutions upon verification of eligible recipients attending the institutions.
If funds cannot be allocated in the fiscal year in which awards are made, priority shall be given to allocating funds for those awards in the following fiscal year.
Each recipient of a scholarship under this section may hold the award for 5 years of full–time study or 8 years of part–time study.
The number of eligible recipients under subsection (d)(3)(v) of this section shall be limited to 15 each year.

An award provided under subsection (d)(3)(vi) of this section may not exceed the amount specified in subsection (e)(2) of this section when combined with any other scholarship received by a student based on the student’s status as a child or spouse of a victim of the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

subsection.text: The Commission:

paragraph.text: May accept any gift or grant from any person for the Edward T. Conroy Scholarship Fund;
Shall use any gift or grant that it receives for a scholarship from the Program; and
Shall deposit any gift or grant that it receives for the Program with the State Treasurer in a nonbudgeted account.

subsection.text: There is a program of scholarships for children of volunteer fire fighters or volunteer ambulance or rescue squad members who died or were disabled by an accident resulting from:

paragraph.text: Performing any duties necessary to the operation or maintenance of the fire company; or
Actively participating in the ambulance or rescue squad work of an incorporated volunteer fire company or volunteer ambulance or rescue squad in the State.

subsection.text: The recipient of a scholarship under this section shall be a graduate of an accredited high school.
The Board of Trustees of the Maryland State Firemen’s Association, in its discretion, shall:

paragraph.text: Determine the amount of each award; and
Select the recipient of each award.

subsection.text: The Maryland State Firemen’s Association shall provide the funds for these awards.
There is a Charles W. Riley Fire and Emergency Medical Services Tuition Reimbursement Program under this section.

As provided in the State budget, any career or volunteer firefighter or ambulance or rescue squad member who is a resident of Maryland shall receive partial or full and complete reimbursement by the Office for tuition costs not to exceed the resident tuition rates at the 4–year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full–time resident undergraduate, for courses credited toward a degree in fire service technology or emergency medical technology.

paragraph.text: The tuition reimbursement application shall be filed with the Office no later than July 1 immediately following the academic year for which tuition reimbursement is sought.
Payment shall be made 1 year after successful completion of each academic year.

Payment may be made only if the applicant is still employed or actively engaged as a career or volunteer firefighter or ambulance or rescue squad member in an organized fire department or ambulance or rescue squad in this State.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, an individual served in the Afghanistan or Iraq conflict if the individual was a member of the uniformed services of the United States who served in:

paragraph.text: Afghanistan or contiguous air space, as defined in federal regulations, on or after October 24, 2001, and before a terminal date to be prescribed by the United States Secretary of Defense; or
Iraq or contiguous waters or air space, as defined in federal regulations, on or after March 19, 2003, and before a terminal date to be prescribed by the United States Secretary of Defense.

subsection.text: There is a Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship.
An individual may apply to the Office for a scholarship under this section if the individual:

paragraph.text: Is a resident of Maryland;

subparagraph.text: Is accepted for admission or enrolled in the regular undergraduate program at an eligible institution; or

Is accepted for admission or enrolled in a 2–year terminal certificate program in which the course work is acceptable for transfer credit for an accredited baccalaureate program in an eligible institution; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Is a veteran, as defined under § 9–901 of the State Government Article, who served in the Afghanistan or Iraq conflict;
Is an active duty member of the armed forces who served in the Afghanistan or Iraq conflict; or

Is a member of a reserve component of the armed forces of the United States or the Maryland National Guard who was activated as a result of the Afghanistan or Iraq conflict described in subsection (a) of this section; or

subparagraph.text: Is a son, daughter, or spouse of:

sub-subparagraph.text: A veteran or active duty member of the armed forces who is serving or has served in the Afghanistan or Iraq conflict; or
A member of the reserve or Maryland National Guard who was activated as a result of the Afghanistan or Iraq conflict described in subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: A scholarship awarded under this section shall supplement any federal education benefits for which a recipient qualifies as a result of an individual’s military service or status as a dependent of a member of the armed forces or of a veteran of the armed forces.

paragraph.text: Each scholarship may be used, at any eligible institution, to pay for educational expenses as defined by the Office, including:

subparagraph.text: Tuition and mandatory fees; and
Room and board.

paragraph.text: The annual amount of a scholarship may not exceed 50% of the equivalent annual tuition, mandatory fees, and room and board of a resident undergraduate student at the 4–year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full–time resident undergraduate.

subsection.text: A scholarship recipient shall maintain a grade point average of at least 2.5 on a 4.0 scale.
Each recipient of a scholarship under this section may hold the award for 5 years of full–time study or 8 years of part–time study.
A scholarship recipient shall file for federal and State financial aid by March 1 of each year.

paragraph.text: The Office may not award an initial scholarship to an individual after June 30, 2020.
The Office may renew a scholarship after June 30, 2020, if the individual received an initial scholarship before that date.

subsection.text: A Senator or Delegate may authorize the Office to award all or a portion of the funds authorized under Subtitles 4 and 5 of this title to eligible recipients of scholarships awarded under this section.

paragraph.text: Funds for the Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.

subparagraph.text: There is a Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship Fund in the Commission.
The Commission:

sub-subparagraph.text: May accept any gift or grant from any person or corporation for the Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship Fund;
Shall use any gift or grant that it receives for a scholarship from the Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship Fund; and
Shall deposit any gift or grant that it receives for the Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship Fund with the State Treasurer in a nonbudgeted account.

subparagraph.text: At the end of the fiscal year, the Commission shall prepare an annual report on the Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship Fund that includes an accounting of all financial receipts and expenditures to and from the Fund.
The Commission shall submit a copy of the report to the General Assembly as provided under § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advisory Council” means the Advisory Council on Workforce Shortage.
“Eligible institution” means a public or private nonprofit institution of higher education in this State that possesses a certificate of approval from the Commission.
“Grant” means the Workforce Shortage Student Assistance grant.

“Public good or benefit” means service to low–income or underserved residents or areas of the State in an occupation in the public sector or in an organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

subsection.text: There is a program of Workforce Shortage Student Assistance grants under this section for students who pledge to work in fields of critical shortage in the State on completion of their studies.
The purpose of the program is to:

paragraph.text: Provide financial assistance to students enrolled at institutions of higher education in the State; and
Address the workforce shortage needs of the State.

subsection.text: A recipient of a Workforce Shortage Student Assistance grant under this section shall:

paragraph.text: Be a resident of the State;
Be selected by the Office from qualified applicants;

Sign a letter of intent to enroll at an eligible institution in the State in an eligible program as specified for each field in which there is a critical shortage in this State as provided in this section;
Sign a letter of intent to perform the service obligation on completion of the recipient’s required studies;
Accept any other conditions attached to the grant;
Satisfy any additional criteria the Commission may establish; and
After completion of studies in an eligible program, perform the service obligation as specified for each field in which there is a critical shortage, as provided in this section.
Except as provided in paragraph (5) of this subsection, the Commission shall on a biennial basis:

subparagraph.text: Identify workforce shortage fields in the State;
Designate eligible workforce shortage fields under the grant program; and
Remove from the grant program any field that the Commission determines no longer qualifies as a workforce shortage.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall appoint an Advisory Council on Workforce Shortage to:

subparagraph.text: Identify workforce shortage fields in the State; and
Recommend to the Commission:

sub-subparagraph.text: Priority workforce shortage fields to be included in the grant program; and
The removal of fields that in the Advisory Council’s judgment no longer qualify as workforce shortage fields.

paragraph.text: In making recommendations to the Commission, the Advisory Council shall consider whether a workforce shortage field provides a public good or benefit to the citizens of Maryland.
The Advisory Council shall include the following members:

subparagraph.text: The Secretary of Higher Education or designee;
The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or designee;
One representative from the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board, appointed by the Governor;
The Secretary of Business and Economic Development or designee;
The Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene or designee;
The State Superintendent of Schools or designee;
One representative of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate;
One representative of the Maryland House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House;
Two representatives from the University System of Maryland, appointed by the Chancellor;
The President of Morgan State University or designee;
The President of St. Mary’s College or designee; and
Representatives nominated by the following organizations and appointed by the Secretary of Higher Education:

sub-subparagraph.text: One representative from the Maryland Chamber of Commerce;
One representative from the Washington Board of Trade;
One representative from the Greater Baltimore Committee;
Two representatives from the Maryland Independent College and University Association;
Two representatives from the Maryland Association of Community Colleges;
One representative from the Maryland Association of Nonprofit Associations; and
One representative from the Financial Assistance Advisory Council representing a financial aid office at an institution of higher education.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the following workforce shortage fields shall be included in the grant program:

sub-subparagraph.text: School teachers (the grant to be known as the Sharon Christa McAuliffe Memorial Teacher Scholarship);
Nurses;
Child care providers;
Developmental disabilities, mental health, child welfare, and juvenile justice providers (the grant to be known as the Ida G. and L. Leonard Ruben Scholarships);
Physical and occupational therapists and assistants; and
Public servants (the grant to be known as the William Donald Schaefer Scholarship and the grant to be known as the Parren J. Mitchell Public Service Scholarship).

subparagraph.text: The Commission may remove a shortage field specified in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph if in the Commission’s judgment the field no longer qualifies as a workforce shortage field.

paragraph.text: A grant recipient in a workforce shortage field that is removed from the grant program may continue to receive renewal awards under the program.

subsection.text: Each fiscal year, the Commission shall determine the number of grants to be awarded in eligible workforce shortage fields based on the:

paragraph.text: Priority of the workforce shortage field;
Severity of the workforce shortage in the field; and
Availability of funds.
The Office shall annually select eligible students and offer a grant to each student selected to be used at an eligible institution of the student’s choice.
Eligible students shall be selected based on academic accomplishment and financial need, as determined by standards established and approved by the Commission.
Each grant shall be renewable for a maximum of 5 years subsequent to the original grant if the recipient:

subparagraph.text: Continues to meet the qualifications specified in subsection (d) of this section; and
Meets satisfactory academic progress standards as determined by the eligible institution.

subsection.text: A grant recipient:

paragraph.text: May be enrolled at an eligible institution on a part–time or full–time basis;
Shall earn at least 12 undergraduate or 9 graduate credit hours in each academic year, including summer sessions;
Except as provided in paragraph (4) of this subsection, shall be an undergraduate student at an eligible institution; and
May be a graduate student if the Office determines that the shortage field requires employees with a graduate level education.

In this subsection, “cost of attendance” means the equivalent annual tuition and mandatory fees of a resident undergraduate student at the 4–year public institution of higher education within the University System of Maryland, other than the University of Maryland University College and University of Maryland, Baltimore, with the highest annual expenses for a full–time resident undergraduate.
Subject to paragraphs (3), (4), and (5) of this subsection, the Commission shall establish in guidelines the annual grant awards under this section.
Annual grant awards shall be within the following ranges:

subparagraph.text: For a part–time student attending a 2–year eligible institution – $1,000 and 12.5% of cost of attendance;
For a full–time student attending a 2–year eligible institution – $2,000 and 25% of cost of attendance;
For a part–time student attending a 4–year eligible institution – $2,000 and 25% of cost of attendance; and
For a full–time student attending a 4–year eligible institution – $4,000 and 50% of cost of attendance.

paragraph.text: For a student taking courses during a summer session to meet the minimum number of credit hours for full–time or part–time status, the Commission shall distribute grant awards to the student in the spring and summer sessions in amounts it determines to be appropriate.

A student who is enrolled in an academic program that includes a mandatory summer academic session as part of the approved curriculum may receive an additional award not to exceed $1,000 per calendar year.

subsection.text: The grant award may be used at any eligible institution for educational expenses as defined by the Commission, including tuition, mandatory fees, and room and board.

paragraph.text: A grant recipient shall perform a service obligation in the recipient’s field of critical shortage in:

subparagraph.text: A full–time position at a rate of 1 year for each year that the recipient receives a grant awarded under this section; or
A part–time position at a rate of 2 years for each year that the recipient receives a grant awarded under this section.

paragraph.text: The Commission may establish alternative service obligation requirements for designated workforce shortage fields to address statewide and regional needs.
A grant recipient shall repay the Commission the funds received as set forth in § 18–112 of this title if the recipient does not:

subparagraph.text: Earn at least 12 undergraduate or 9 graduate credit hours in each academic year in which the student receives assistance, including summer sessions;
Complete the specified degree, attain the licensure or certification required, or fulfill other requirements as provided in this section; or
Perform the service obligation required under subsection (k) of this section.

paragraph.text: The Office shall waive the repayment of a grant award at a rate of:

subparagraph.text: 1 year for each year that the recipient performs the service obligation on a full–time basis; or
6 months for each year that the recipient performs the service obligation on a part–time basis.

paragraph.text: A recipient shall begin repayment at any time during the period that the recipient is no longer performing the service obligation.
A recipient may delay repayment as long as the recipient remains a student enrolled at least part–time in a degree–granting program.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, repayment shall be made to the State within 6 years after the repayment period begins and shall follow a repayment schedule established by the Office.
The Office may waive or defer repayment in the event of disability or extended sickness which prevents the recipient from fulfilling the service obligation required under this section.
The Office shall grant a deferment from the service obligation required under this section to:

subparagraph.text: An individual who has been assigned military duty outside the State; or
The spouse of an individual who has been assigned military duty outside the State.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies to recipients of the William Donald Schaefer Scholarship specified in subsection (e)(5) of this section.

The Commission shall annually select eligible students and offer grants to students who demonstrate outstanding potential for and who plan to pursue a career in public service to assist in providing legal services to low–income residents in the State.

In making William Donald Schaefer Scholarship awards under this section, the Commission shall endeavor to select award recipients who are representative of the State’s rich cultural, geographic, racial, ethnic, and gender diversity.

Each individual awarded a William Donald Schaefer Scholarship under this section must have indicated and demonstrated to the Commission a serious intent to enter public service on the completion of the student’s educational program.
This subsection applies to recipients of the Parren J. Mitchell Public Service Scholarship specified in subsection (e)(5) of this section.

The Commission shall annually select eligible students and offer grants to students who demonstrate outstanding potential for and who plan to pursue a career in public service and assist in providing:

subparagraph.text: Social work services to low–income residents in the State;
Nursing services in nursing shortage areas in the State as defined in § 18–802 of this title; or
Other services in the public or nonprofit sectors in which there is a shortage of qualified practitioners to low–income or underserved residents or areas of the State.

paragraph.text: In making Parren J. Mitchell Public Service Scholarship awards under this section, the Commission shall endeavor to select award recipients who are representative of the State’s rich cultural, geographic, racial, ethnic, and gender diversity.

Each individual awarded a Parren J. Mitchell Public Service Scholarship under this section must have indicated and demonstrated to the Commission a serious intent to enter public service on the completion of the student’s educational program.
There is a Workforce Shortage Student Assistance Grant Fund in the Commission.
The Commission:

subparagraph.text: May accept any gift or grant from any person or corporation for the Workforce Shortage Student Assistance Grant Fund;
Shall use any gift or grant that it receives for a grant award from the Fund; and
Shall deposit any gift or grant that it receives for the Fund with the State Treasurer in a nonbudgeted account.

At the end of the fiscal year, the Commission shall prepare an annual report on the Workforce Shortage Student Assistance Grant Fund that includes an accounting of all financial receipts and expenditures to and from the Fund.
The Commission shall submit a copy of the report to the General Assembly as provided under § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: A recipient may hold a Workforce Shortage Student Assistance grant and any other State grant or scholarship awarded by the Office provided that the total of all grants and scholarships does not exceed:

paragraph.text: The student’s total cost of attendance, as certified by the institution where the student is enrolled; and
The cost of attendance, as defined in subsection (i) of this section.

subsection.text: Funds for the Workforce Shortage Student Assistance grant program shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.
The Commission shall adopt guidelines or regulations necessary to implement this section.
Each county may establish a program of county scholarships for students of medicine, dentistry, or nursing, and may levy and pay any amount required for this purpose.

The county council, board of county commissioners, or Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may determine the amount to be awarded, the number of these scholarships, and the method of selecting the recipients.
An award granted under this section:

paragraph.text: May not be held by the same student for more than 4 years; and
May be used for educational expenses, including:

subparagraph.text: Tuition and mandatory fees;
Room and board; and
Books.

subsection.text: Each recipient of a scholarship under this section shall give a bond to the county, with security satisfactory to it, that after graduation he will practice his profession in the county for at least:

paragraph.text: 5 years if the scholarship is for medicine or dentistry; or
3 years if the scholarship is for nursing.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Medical education center” means an institution:

subparagraph.text: Whose objectives include the education of medical and allied health personnel; and
That has residency programs or full departments in at least three primary care areas.

paragraph.text: “Nurse practitioner” means a nurse practitioner as defined by the rules and regulations of the State Board of Nursing.
“Physician assistant” means an individual to whom duties are delegated by a licensed physician under the rules and regulations of the State Board of Physicians.
“Primary care” means family practice, general internal medicine, and general pediatrics.

“Eligible organization” means an institution, including a licensed hospital, nursing home, adult day care center, public health agency, home health agency, or other organization authorized by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene.
“Eligible institution” means an institution of postsecondary education:

subparagraph.text: Approved to operate by the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
That awards nursing degrees or diplomas.

paragraph.text: “Nursing shortage area” means a recognized area of nursing service or specialization determined by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene to be an area where there exists a shortage of qualified nurses in eligible organizations.
“Nursing student” means a student enrolled in a postsecondary nursing education degree or diploma program at an eligible institution.

There is a Maryland Physician Assistant-Nurse Practitioner Training Program that provides financial support to institutions with training programs for physician assistants and nurse practitioners in primary care in this State administered by the Office. An institution may participate if its program:

subparagraph.text: Is accredited by the American Medical Association, the American Nurses Association, or the National League of Nursing;
Produces graduates eligible to take:

sub-subparagraph.text: The primary care physician assistant certifying examination of the National Commission on the Certification of Physician Assistants; or
The primary care in adult and family nursing practice certifying examination or any other examination required by the State Board of Nursing;

subparagraph.text: Is part of, or has a formal arrangement with, a medical education center;
Focuses on developing primary care skills and includes substantial clinical experience in primary care; and
Is not a specialty program in a discipline other than primary care.

paragraph.text: The Physician Assistant-Nurse Practitioner Training Program consists of grants to an eligible medical education center for each individual who completes the program in physician assistant or nurse practitioner training in the amount of:

subparagraph.text: $3,000 for each physician assistant; and
$1,500 for each nurse practitioner.

subsection.text: If the total amount of the grants to be made under this section for physician assistants-nurse practitioners is more than $72,000 annually, then the amount of a medical education center’s grant for that period shall be equal to the product of:

paragraph.text: The amount required to pay grants for that center; times
The ratio of the total amount appropriated to the total amount required to pay grants under this section to all centers.

subsection.text: A grant may not be awarded to a medical education center that has discontinued its program in physician assistant or nurse practitioner training.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Grant” means the Health Personnel Shortage Incentive Grant for eligible institutions offering educational programs leading to licensure, certification, or registration in health occupations determined to be in short supply.
“Eligible institution” means an institution of postsecondary education that:

subparagraph.text: Is approved to operate by the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
Produces graduates eligible to take the appropriate national examination for licensure, certification, or registration in the relevant health occupation determined to be in short supply.

paragraph.text: “Health occupation” means a:

subparagraph.text: Physical therapist or a physical therapist assistant who has at least an Associate degree in physical therapy;
Occupational therapist or an occupational therapist assistant who has at least an Associate degree in occupational therapy;
Radiographer;
Respiratory therapist;
Laboratory technician;
Medical technologist;
Pharmacist;
Registered nurse or licensed practical nurse; or
Physician who engages in family practice or pediatrics.

paragraph.text: There is a Health Personnel Shortage Incentive Grant Program for eligible institutions.
The Office of Student Financial Assistance shall administer the Grant Program as provided in this section.
In consultation with the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene, the Office shall adopt regulations to implement the Grant Program.

subsection.text: An eligible institution is qualified to receive a grant under this section if the institution:

paragraph.text: Has an approved education program leading to licensure, certification, or registration in a health occupation determined to be in short supply; and
Funds the approved education program at an amount not less than the preceding fiscal year.

Except as provided in subsection (e) of this section, an eligible institution shall receive a grant in the amount of $1,500 for each student who graduates from an approved education program leading to licensure, certification, or registration in a health occupation determined to be in short supply, that is in excess of the lowest number of students who graduated from the approved education program at that eligible institution commencing in the academic year 1990-91.
For purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Commission shall establish, in consultation with each appropriate eligible institution, that institution’s threshold number of students.

If the total amount of the grant to be issued under subsection (d) of this section is more than the amount appropriated in the annual State budget, including the amount that is collected under the Board of Physicians Fund under § 14-207(c)(2)(i) of the Health Occupations Article and transferred to this program, the amount of an eligible institution’s grant for that period shall be equal to the product of the amount required to pay grants under subsection (d) multiplied by the ratio of the total amount appropriated to the eligible institution.

Any unspent portions of the money that is transferred to the Office for use under this section by the Comptroller may not be transferred to or revert to the General Fund of the State, but shall remain in the Fund maintained by the Office to administer these programs to be used for the purposes specified in this section.

subsection.text: The eligible institution shall use the grant to enhance or expand approved education programs leading to licensure or certification in health occupations determined to be in short supply.

paragraph.text: In accordance with § 1-204 of the Health Occupations Article, the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene shall certify annually to the Maryland Higher Education Commission those health occupations in short supply.

In any year in which a health occupation is determined by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene to be no longer in short supply, the Office shall discontinue issuing new grants under this section for that health occupation, provided that the existing grants shall continue for the students who are enrolled in prior to and who subsequently graduate from the approved education program after the determination is made by the Secretary.

subsection.text: There is a program of fellowships for postgraduate work in the Graduate School of the University of Maryland, College Park known as the Judith A. Resnik Memorial Postgraduate Fellowship Program.
Each recipient of a fellowship awarded under this section:

paragraph.text: Shall be a graduate of a standard 4-year college course in an institution of higher education accredited by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools or an equivalent regional accrediting agency; and
Shall be recommended for graduate study by the executive head of the institution from which he graduated.

subsection.text: If possible, residents of this State shall receive preference in the award of these fellowships.

The University of Maryland shall cooperate with the accredited institutions of higher education in this State by specifying each year the requirements of the graduate school, the standards for determining eligibility for fellowships, and the fields of greatest need for qualified faculty in the public institutions of higher education in this State.
Each fellowship:

paragraph.text: May not be for less than $200 a single year or for more than the highest 10-month stipend for a graduate assistant.
May be held for 3 years if the recipient:

subparagraph.text: Continues to be a full-time student at the University of Maryland and carries at least 12 semester hours of courses each semester;
In the judgment of the University, is making satisfactory progress towards a degree; and
Maintains the department standards of the University.

paragraph.text: Each year, the fellowship committee of the University shall certify not more than 18 fellowships to qualified applicants as the amount appropriated to the program that year allows.
The award of such fellowships shall be made when possible so as to promote compliance with the State of Maryland desegregation goals.
If possible:

subparagraph.text: The distribution shall be made as wide as possible to graduates of accredited institutions of higher education in this State; and
Consideration shall be given to the greatest need in securing qualified faculties in the public institutions of higher education in this State.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**

There is a Distinguished Scholar Program of 350 scholarships to be awarded by the Office to residents of the State in the manner provided in this subtitle for use at postsecondary institutions of higher education in the State.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**

subsection.text: The Office shall annually select the 350 secondary school students who have the greatest potential for academic success in higher education as determined by criteria established by the Office and offer a scholarship to each of these students to be used at any Maryland postsecondary institution of the student’s choice, if the student meets the following qualifications:

paragraph.text: Qualifies academically as follows:

subparagraph.text: Has a secondary school transcript indicating an overall academic grade point average of at least 3.7 on a 4.0 scale or its equivalent grade point average;
Is a finalist of the National Merit Scholarship Program or the Achievement Scholarship Program administered by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation; or
Has a superior creative talent or skill in art, music, dance, or the theater, as determined by an audition or portfolio review process established by the Office;

paragraph.text: Has matriculated at a postsecondary educational institution in the State; and
Qualifies as a Maryland resident.

At least 150 of the 350 awards shall be granted to superior academic achievers whose secondary school transcripts indicate after the first semester of the junior year an overall academic grade point average of at least 3.7 on a 4.0 scale, or its equivalent grade point average.
At least 2 recipients who meet the qualifications specified under this section shall be selected from each county of the State.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the scholarship award shall be in the amount of $3,000 for use in the next ensuing academic year.
A recipient’s award may not exceed the cost of attendance at the institution, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: The tuition and fees applicable to the student; and

The institution’s estimate of other expenses reasonably related to cost of attendance at that institution, including, without limitation, the cost of room and board, transportation, books, and supplies.

paragraph.text: If it is accepted by the eligible student, each award shall be renewable, on an annual basis, for a maximum of 3 years subsequent to the original award if the recipient:

subparagraph.text: Remains a resident of the State;
Attends an accredited postsecondary institution in the State;
Is enrolled as a full–time undergraduate student; and
Maintains a 3.0 grade average on an academic year basis or, failing to do so, provides evidence, satisfactory to the Secretary, of extenuating circumstances of extreme personal hardship.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**

The Office shall annually select a number of alternate scholarship awards under this subtitle. In the event the annual number of awards is not made, as provided in § 18–1101 of this subtitle, the Office may make an award from the alternate list as necessary to assure that 350 awards are made annually.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**
An award granted under this subtitle may be used for:

paragraph.text: Tuition and mandatory fees;
Room and board; and
Books and supplies.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**
These scholarship awards are in addition to any other State scholarships that are available to the student.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**

subsection.text: There is a Distinguished Scholar Program for Community College Transfer Students to be awarded by the Office to residents of the State in the manner provided in this section for use at 4–year institutions of higher education in the State.

The Office shall annually select the community college students who have the greatest potential for academic success in higher education as determined by criteria established by the Office and offer a scholarship to each of these students to be used at any Maryland 4–year institution of higher education of the student’s choice, if the student meets the following qualifications:

paragraph.text: Has a community college transcript indicating an overall academic grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale or its equivalent grade point average;
Has completed at least 60 credit hours or an associate degree program at a community college in the State;
Qualifies as a Maryland resident;
Applies the scholarship within 1 year of completing the required credit hours or an associate degree program; and
Attends the 4–year institution of higher education as a full–time student.

subsection.text: The Office shall award scholarships under this section to recipients who have attended community colleges from across the State.

paragraph.text: The scholarship award shall be in the amount of $3,000 per academic year.
Each award shall be renewable for a maximum of 1 year subsequent to the original award if the recipient:

subparagraph.text: Continues to meet the qualifications specified in subsection (b) of this section; and
Maintains a 3.0 grade point average on an academic year basis.

subsection.text: An award granted under this subtitle may be used for:

paragraph.text: Tuition and mandatory fees;
Room and board; and
Books and supplies.

subsection.text: This scholarship award is in addition to any other State scholarships that are available to the student.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: ** IN EFFECT UNTIL JULY 1, 2015 PER CHAPTER 397 OF 2011**
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Commission may not award any new scholarships under this subtitle for the 2011–2012 academic year or for any subsequent academic year.
There is a program of private career school student grants in this State, known as the Jack F. Tolbert Memorial Student Grant Program, that are awarded under this subtitle.
The Office shall administer the program of private career school student financial aid grants.

subsection.text: The Office may not require any competitive examination in determining student eligibility.
Each applicant for a private career school student grant shall:

paragraph.text: Be accepted for admission at an approved private career school;
Be enrolled in a full-time program as determined by the Maryland Higher Education Commission;
Be a resident of this State; and
Demonstrate to the Office financial need.

section.text: A private career school student grant may be awarded in $100 increments. However, an award for a single year may not be more than $1,500.

subsection.text: A private career school student grant may be used at a private career school in this State that:

paragraph.text: Is approved by the Maryland Higher Education Commission;
Operates solely within the State;
Does not have an outstanding notice of deficiencies under appeal in accordance with the regulations adopted by the Higher Education Commission;
Does not have a negative final report under the State Postsecondary Review Program in accordance with 34 C.F.R. § 667.23 as the regulation may be amended; and
Has not been referred for review under the State Postsecondary Review Program as a result of its student loan default rates in accordance with 34 C.F.R. § 667.5 as the regulation may be amended.

subsection.text: A grant awarded under this subtitle may be used for tuition charges only.

section.text: Each recipient of a private career school student grant may hold the grant for 2 years if the student:

paragraph.text: Continues to be a resident of this State;
Continues to be enrolled in a full-time program;
In the judgment of the institution, is making satisfactory progress toward a certificate of completion; and
Continues to demonstrate a financial need.

section.text: The Governor shall include in the annual budget bill an appropriation to the Program in an amount not less than $200,000 for the fiscal year that begins on July 1, 1996 and each subsequent fiscal year.

subsection.text: In this section, “part–time student” means a student who:

paragraph.text: Is enrolled in a degree–granting program at an eligible institution and taking at least 3 but no more than 11 semester hours of courses each semester; or
Is dually enrolled in a secondary school in the State and an institution of higher education.

subsection.text: In cooperation with the institutions of higher education in the State, the Commission shall establish and administer a grant program for undergraduate part–time students.
A recipient of a part–time grant shall:

paragraph.text: Be a resident of the State; and
Have demonstrated a definite financial need according to criteria established by the Commission.

subsection.text: For courses completed under the program, a recipient who is dually enrolled in a secondary school in the State and an institution of higher education may not be required to receive credit from a secondary school and an institution of higher education at the same time.

paragraph.text: Funds for the Part–Time Grant Program shall be allocated by the Commission to each institution of higher education based upon the number of undergraduate part–time students with demonstrated financial need who are enrolled in degree–granting programs at the institution.

An institution of higher education may use up to 10% of the part–time grant allocation to provide grants to students who are enrolled in at least 3 but less than 6 semester hours of courses each semester.

subsection.text: In addition to the funds provided under § 18–14A–02(b) of this title, institutions may use up to 10% of the part–time grant allocation to provide grants to students who are dually enrolled.
Funds for the grant program for part–time students shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.

section.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: Establish guidelines for the awarding of grants to part-time students; and
Adopt any other guidelines or regulations necessary for the administration of this subtitle.

section.text: An institution of higher education that receives State funds under this subtitle shall provide the Commission with an annual audit describing the disposition of the funds.

subsection.text: In this section, “dually enrolled student” means a student who is dually enrolled in:

paragraph.text: A secondary school in the State; and
An institution of higher education in the State.

subsection.text: In cooperation with institutions of higher education in the State, the Commission shall establish and administer a grant program for dually enrolled students.
A recipient of an early college access grant shall:

paragraph.text: Be a resident of the State;
Be a dually enrolled student; and
Demonstrate financial need according to criteria established by the Commission.

subsection.text: For courses completed under the program, a recipient of an early college access grant is not required to receive credit from a secondary school and an institution of higher education at the same time.

Funds for the Early College Access Grant Program shall be allocated by the Commission to an institution of higher education based on the number of dually enrolled students receiving credit for courses completed at the institution.
Funds for the Early College Access Grant Program shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.

section.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: Establish guidelines for the awarding of early college access grants to dually enrolled students; and
Adopt any other guidelines or regulations necessary for the administration of this subtitle.

section.text: An institution of higher education that receives State funds under this subtitle shall provide the Commission with an annual audit of the use of the funds.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Eligible field of employment” means employment in the State by an organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
“Eligible field of employment” includes employment by the State or any local government in the State, but does not include being employed as a judicial clerk in any court.

subsection.text: “Higher education loan” means any loan for undergraduate or graduate study that is obtained for tuition, educational expenses, or living expenses from:

paragraph.text: A college or university, government, or commercial source; or
An organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program.
There is a program of loan assistance repayment known as the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program in the State.
The Office of Student Financial Assistance shall assist in the repayment of the amount of any higher education loan owed by an individual who:

subparagraph.text: Receives a graduate, professional, or undergraduate degree from:

sub-subparagraph.text: A college or university in the State of Maryland; or
A school of law; or

subparagraph.text: Receives a Resident Teacher Certificate (RTC) from the Department after completing an alternative teaching preparation program approved by the State Superintendent;

paragraph.text: Obtains eligible employment;
Receives an income that is less than the maximum eligible total income levels established by the Office, including any additional sources of income; and
Satisfies any other criteria established by the Office.

subsection.text: Subject to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, the Office shall assist in the repayment of the amount of any higher education loan owed by a public school teacher in the State who:

paragraph.text: Has taught in Maryland for at least 2 years:

subparagraph.text: In science, technology, engineering, or math subjects; or
In a school in which at least 75% of the students are enrolled in the free and reduced lunch program in the State for 2 years; and

paragraph.text: Has received the highest performance evaluation rating for the most recent year available in the county in which the teacher taught (the grant to be known as the Nancy Grasmick Teacher Award).

subsection.text: A recipient of a Nancy Grasmick Teacher Award shall be known as a Nancy Grasmick Teacher Scholar.

An applicant for assistance in the repayment of a commercial loan shall demonstrate to the Office that the commercial loan was used for tuition, educational expenses, or living expenses for graduate or undergraduate study.
Assistance in the repayment of a loan from an entity set forth in § 18–1501(c)(2) of this subtitle shall require the approval of the Office.
The Office of Student Financial Assistance shall adopt regulations to establish:

paragraph.text: The maximum starting income for eligibility in the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program;
The maximum total income for eligibility in the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program, including any additional sources of income;
That priority for participation in the Program shall be given to an individual who:

subparagraph.text: Graduated from an institution of higher education in the last 3 years;
Is a resident of the State;
Is employed on a full–time basis; and
