sub-subparagraph.text: Provides, as the principal part of the individual’s employment, legal services to low–income residents in the State who cannot afford legal services, nursing services in nursing shortage areas in the State as defined in § 18–802 of this title, or other services in an eligible field of employment in which there is a shortage of qualified practitioners to low–income or underserved residents or areas of the State; or
For teacher applicants only, qualifies for a Nancy Grasmick Teacher Award;

paragraph.text: A limit on the total amount of assistance provided by the Office of Student Financial Assistance in repaying the loan of an eligible individual, based on the individual’s total income and outstanding higher education loan balance;
A procedure and schedule for the payment of the amount of loan assistance provided by the Office of Student Financial Assistance to the eligible individual; and
An annual review of the eligibility of each individual participating in the Program.

subsection.text: The Office of Student Financial Assistance may not approve more than 50% of the total number of awards for teacher applicants to Nancy Grasmick Teacher Scholars.
The Office of Student Financial Assistance shall adopt any other regulations necessary to implement this subtitle.
Funds for the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program described in subsection (b)(2) of this section shall be allocated by the Commission to an individual who:

paragraph.text: Has received a graduate degree from a school of law; and
Has submitted an application for the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program that the Commission disapproved due to insufficient funds.

subsection.text: Funds for the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program shall:

paragraph.text: Be provided on an annual basis in the State budget; and
Include money paid to the Program from the fee charged for a special admission of an out–of–state attorney under § 7–202(e) of the Courts Article.

subsection.text: If a federal matching grant loan program furnishes professional services in an eligible field of employment to low–income or underserved residents of the State, the Office may apply not more than 50 percent of the funds provided in the State budget for the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program to the State’s participation in the federal program.

section.text: Subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the Office of Student Financial Assistance shall report to the General Assembly by January 1 of each year on the implementation of the Janet L. Hoffman Loan Assistance Repayment Program.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible employment” means full-time employment in the State in an occupation requiring a college or university degree in a math or science program.
“Higher education loan” means any loan for undergraduate study that is obtained for tuition, educational expenses, or living expenses from:

paragraph.text: A college or university, government, or commercial source; or
An organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

subsection.text: There is a Math/Science Student Corps to encourage students to enroll in math and science programs and work in occupations in Maryland requiring math and science skills.

The purpose of the program is to increase the number of graduates who are employed in occupations requiring math and science skills and to provide loan repayment assistance for graduates who work in Maryland.
The Office may assist in the repayment of any higher education loan owed by an individual who:

paragraph.text: Receives an undergraduate degree in a math or science program from a college or university in Maryland;
Obtains eligible employment;
Participates in activities to encourage other students to pursue math and science degree programs and occupations as may be required by the Office; and
Satisfies any other criteria established by the Office.

subsection.text: Recipients of loan repayment assistance may participate in the program for a maximum of 4 years.

An applicant for assistance in the repayment of a commercial loan shall demonstrate to the Office that the commercial loan was used for tuition, educational expenses, or living expenses for undergraduate study.
Assistance in the repayment of a loan from an entity set forth in § 18-1601(c)(2) of this subtitle shall require the approval of the Office.
The Office shall adopt guidelines or regulations to establish:

paragraph.text: The math and science degree programs and occupations eligible for the program and review them on an annual basis;
The criteria for making loan repayment assistance awards;
A procedure and schedule for the Office to pay eligible individual loan repayment assistance; and
An annual review of the eligibility of each individual participating in the program.

subsection.text: The Office shall adopt any other guidelines or regulations necessary to implement this subtitle.

section.text: Funds for the Math/Science Student Corps shall be as provided by the Governor in the annual budget of the Commission.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible student” means a junior, senior, or graduate student who attends an institution of higher education in the State.
“Program” means the Walter Sondheim Jr. Public Service Summer Internship Scholarship Program.
“Shriver Center” means the Shriver Center located at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.
“Summer internship” means a paid or unpaid summer internship in the State with:

paragraph.text: An organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that:

subparagraph.text: Is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; and

Affords the student the opportunity to participate in and support management functions, including board governance, executive leadership, financial management, human resources, fundraising, or facilities management; or

paragraph.text: The State or any local government in the State.

subsection.text: There is a scholarship program known as the Walter Sondheim Jr. Public Service Summer Internship Scholarship Program in the State.
The purpose of the Program is to assist college and graduate students to explore public service career opportunities through summer internships.
The Shriver Center shall administer the Program.
On or before January 1 of each year, an institution of higher education in the State may nominate eligible students to participate in the Program.
Priority for participation in the Program shall be given to an eligible student who:

paragraph.text: Is a resident of the State;
Has demonstrated an interest in a career in public service; and
Assists in providing:

subparagraph.text: Legal services:

sub-subparagraph.text: To low–income residents in the State who cannot afford legal services; or
In a public service position;

subparagraph.text: Social work services to low–income residents in the State;
Nursing services in nursing shortage areas in the State as defined in § 18–802 of this title; or
Other services in the public or nonprofit sectors in which there is a shortage of qualified practitioners to low–income or underserved residents or areas of the State.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, on or before May 1 of each year, the Shriver Center shall award scholarships to eligible students who have agreed to serve in a public service summer internship.
The Shriver Center shall award no more than:

subparagraph.text: 75 scholarships for the summer of 2008; and
100 scholarships for the summer of 2009.

paragraph.text: Funds for the scholarships awarded under this subtitle shall be as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: Subject to the availability of funds, the scholarship award under the Program shall be $3,000.
The Shriver Center shall serve as a clearinghouse for public and nonprofit entities who wish to hire public service summer interns participating in the Program.
The Shriver Center shall adopt policies to establish:

paragraph.text: The criteria for eligibility in the Program;
A procedure and schedule for the payment of the scholarship award provided to an eligible student; and
A procedure for the repayment of the scholarship award if a student does not fulfill the internship requirements under the Program.

subsection.text: The Shriver Center shall adopt any other policies necessary to implement this subtitle.
Funds for the Walter Sondheim Jr. Public Service Summer Internship Scholarship Program may be provided on an annual basis in the State budget.
The Governor may provide funding in the State budget to the Shriver Center to administer the Program.

section.text: Subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the Shriver Center shall report to the General Assembly by January 1 of each year on the implementation of the Program.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Grant” means an apprenticeship incentive grant that is awarded to an apprenticeship sponsor under this subtitle.
“Grant recipient” means a person or entity that receives a grant under this subtitle.
“Program” means the Apprenticeship Incentive Program.

The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation in collaboration with the State Superintendent of Schools and the Secretary of Higher Education may establish a program of school-to-work transition grants, to be known as the “Youth Apprenticeship Program”.
Funds for the program shall be as provided by the Governor in the annual budget.
A grant may be awarded under this subtitle to:

paragraph.text: An employer or consortium of employers;
An industrial trade association;
A trade union;
A registered apprenticeship sponsor; or
A combination of the entities specified in items (1) through (4) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A grant recipient shall use the grant in an apprenticeship training program that is:

paragraph.text: A registered apprenticeship program approved by the Apprenticeship and Training Council within the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
A youth apprenticeship program approved by the State Superintendent of Schools that involves students attending the public schools of the State; or
A youth apprenticeship program approved by the Secretary of Juvenile Services that involves clients of the Department of Juvenile Services.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may ensure that the youth apprenticeship programs approved under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: Foster the expansion of structured, school-to-work transition programs that link secondary school applied learning experiences with:

subparagraph.text: Skilled, high wage, workplace jobs and professions; and
Postsecondary technical and occupational work experiences;

paragraph.text: Foster enrollment in apprenticeship programs that target youth, including general education degree recipients;

Foster enrollment of inexperienced, unskilled, first time hires in long-term programs leading to a credential in emerging, technology based occupations that are projected as high growth areas in the State economy; and

Support the development of competency based instructional programs that encompass secondary and postsecondary institutions and are based on specific skill standards that are identified by the industry through accepted models.

subsection.text: The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, after consultation with the Advisory Board and interested potential grant recipients, may establish guidelines for the review and evaluation of grant proposals and the selection of grant recipients.

paragraph.text: During the month of January each year, the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may issue a request for proposals inviting interested persons to submit grant proposals for participation in the program for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 of that year.

Grant proposals may be received and reviewed by the Department only during the period between the date of the issuance of the request for proposals under paragraph (1) of this subsection and May 31 of that year.

The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may evaluate grant proposals on a competitive basis and shall approve only proposals that it determines are of high quality and likely to fulfill the goals and objectives of the program.

Following a review of all grant proposals received during the period specified under subsection (b) of this section, the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may announce the grant recipients for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 of that year.

section.text: If a Youth Apprenticeship Program is established under the authority granted under this subtitle, the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may:

paragraph.text: Determine the amount that is needed to fund the grants awarded under this subtitle; and
Submit this information to the Department of Budget and Management for inclusion in the annual budget.

subsection.text: The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may require that each grant recipient have a matching requirement for the amount of the grant that is awarded to the recipient under this subtitle.

The grant recipient may include in the amount that is calculated as its match under subsection (a) of this section the costs of personnel, equipment, and materials it incurs in the training program for the students it enrolls.
The grant recipient may use the grant for:

paragraph.text: The development of competency based instructional programs that incorporate industry skills and that are based on generally accepted models within the industry;
The development of performance assessment systems that are tied to industry standards that demonstrate mastery of skills with a formal credential;
The coordination of work site and on-the-job training; and
To the extent not provided by the educational institution attended by the student or by any other entity, the costs of tuition, books, fees, and materials used in the training program.

subsection.text: Funds for the costs of the administration of the program shall be as provided by the Governor in the annual budget.
The grant recipient shall:

paragraph.text: Submit periodic reports to the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation summarizing its activities under the program;
Meet and consult with the Secretary about the program; and
Make available to the Secretary for inspection, the recipient’s books, accounts, and other records associated with the program at such times as are mutually agreed upon by the parties.

subsection.text: The Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation may establish a Youth Apprenticeship Program Advisory Board.
The Advisory Board shall include:

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
The State Superintendent of Schools;
The Secretary of Higher Education;
The chair of the Maryland Business Roundtable, or the chair’s designee;
The President of the Maryland AFL-CIO, or the President’s designee;
The chair of the Maryland Apprenticeship and Training Council, or the chair’s designee;
The chair of the Partnership for Workforce Quality Advisory Board, or the chair’s designee;
The chair of the Vocational Education Advisory Council, or the chair’s designee;
The chair of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board, or the chair’s designee;
The chair of the Maryland Association of Community Colleges, or the chair’s designee;
One member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate; and
One member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: The Advisory Board shall, from time to time, review the program and advise the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, the State Superintendent of Schools, and the Secretary of Higher Education about matters regarding the program.

section.text: The Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, in collaboration with the State Superintendent of Schools and the Secretary of Higher Education, may adopt regulations to implement the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Account holder” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: Makes or undertakes the obligation to make advance payments of qualified higher education expenses as provided under a prepaid contract; and
Except as provided in § 18–1909(b) of this subtitle, is a resident of Maryland or of the District of Columbia at the time that the account holder enters into a prepaid contract.

subsection.text: “Board” means the College Savings Plans of Maryland Board.
“Broker–Dealer Plan” means the Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan established under Subtitle 19B of this title.
“Current prepaid contract obligations” means the scheduled payments due for the next fiscal year under existing prepaid contracts.
“Eligible institution of higher education” means an institution of higher education that:

paragraph.text: Offers an associate, bachelor, or graduate degree program; and
Is eligible to participate in federal financial aid programs.

subsection.text: “Market value of program assets” means the amount of cash and cash equivalents held by the Trust plus the fair market value of other assets of the Trust.
“Plan” means the Maryland College Investment Plan established under Subtitle 19A of this title.

“Prepaid contract” means a contract between the Board and an account holder under the provisions of this subtitle for the advance payment of qualified higher education expenses by the account holder for a qualified beneficiary to attend an eligible institution of higher education, if the qualified beneficiary is admitted to the institution.
“Program” means the College Savings Plans of Maryland.
“Qualified beneficiary” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: Is eligible to apply advance payments of qualified higher education expenses to undergraduate or graduate qualified higher education expenses at an eligible institution of higher education under the provisions of this subtitle; and
Except as provided in § 18–1909(b) of this subtitle, is a resident of the State or of the District of Columbia at the time that the account holder enters into a prepaid contract.

subsection.text: “Qualified higher education expenses” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Qualified state tuition program” has the meaning stated in § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Trust” means the Maryland Prepaid College Trust established under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Tuition” means the actual tuition and mandatory fees assessed to all students by an eligible institution of higher education as a condition of enrollment at the institution.

“Tuition” does not include any fee that is assessed by the institution for a particular course taken, year of enrollment, academic status, course of study, residency status, or any other distinguishing factor used by the institution to determine a specific fee.

section.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly to enhance the accessibility and affordability of higher education for all citizens of the State and for all citizens of the District of Columbia by establishing a method to provide for the prepayment of tuition at eligible institutions of higher education.

subsection.text: There is a Program entitled the College Savings Plans of Maryland.

The purpose of the Program is to provide for the administration by the Board of the Maryland Prepaid College Trust, the Maryland College Investment Plan, and the Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan.
There is a Maryland Prepaid College Trust.
The purpose of the Trust is to provide:

paragraph.text: A means for payment of the cost of tuition in advance of enrollment at an eligible institution of higher education; and

An assurance to a beneficiary who enrolls at an eligible institution of higher education that the Board shall make every effort to invest the advance payments so that the prepaid contract will cover the average in-State tuition costs at public institutions of higher education in the State at the time that the benefits are exercised.

subsection.text: The Board shall administer the Trust in compliance with Internal Revenue Service standards for qualified State tuition programs.
The funds of the Trust consist of:

paragraph.text: Payments received from prepaid contracts made under the provisions of this subtitle;
Bequests, endowments, or funds from any other available private source;
Interest and income earned from the investments of the Trust; and
Federal, State, or local funds, or funds from any other available public source.

subsection.text: Money remaining in the Trust at the end of the fiscal year shall remain in the Trust and may not revert to the General Fund of the State.
Moneys of the Trust may not be considered moneys of the State and may not be deposited into the Treasury.
Moneys of the Trust may not be considered moneys of the Maryland College Investment Plan and may not be commingled with the Plan.

paragraph.text: The debts, contracts, and obligations of the Trust are not the contracts, debts, or obligations of the State and neither the faith and credit nor taxing power of the State is pledged directly or indirectly or contingently, morally or otherwise, to the payment of the debts, contracts, and obligations.

The Board cannot directly or indirectly or contingently obligate, morally or otherwise, the State to levy or pledge any form of taxation whatsoever for the debts and obligations of the Trust or to make any appropriation for the payment of the debts and obligations of the Trust.

subsection.text: Neither the State nor any eligible institution of higher education shall be liable for any losses or shortage of funds in the event that the Maryland Prepaid College Trust is insufficient to meet the tuition requirements of an institution attended by the qualified beneficiary.
There is a College Savings Plans of Maryland Board.
The Board shall administer:

paragraph.text: The Maryland Prepaid College Trust established under this subtitle;
The Maryland College Investment Plan established under Subtitle 19A of this title; and
The Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan established under Subtitle 19B of this title.

subsection.text: The Board consists of the following 10 members:

paragraph.text: The Secretary of the Maryland Higher Education Commission;
The State Superintendent of Schools;
The State Treasurer;
The State Comptroller;
The Chancellor of the University System of Maryland; and

Five members of the public who shall be appointed by the Governor and shall have significant experience in finance, accounting, investment management, or other areas that can be of assistance to the Board.

subsection.text: A member of the Board designated under subsection (c)(1) through (5) of this section may designate an employee from the member’s staff to represent the member of the Board, with the full voting rights, powers, and duties of the member.
Before taking office, each appointee to the Board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: Except for the terms of the initial members of the Board, the term of a public member of the Board is 4 years.
The terms of the public members of the Board are staggered as required by the terms of the members of the Board on October 1, 1998.
At the end of a term, a public member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A public member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the remainder of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A public member is eligible for reappointment.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a public member for incompetence or misconduct.
The Board, from among the members of the Board, shall elect a chairman and may elect additional officers that the Board considers necessary.
The Board shall determine the times and places of meetings.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: May not receive compensation;
Is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations; and
Shall file a public disclosure of financial interests as required under the Maryland Public Ethics Law.
The Board:

subparagraph.text: Shall appoint a Program executive director who is in the executive service of the State Personnel Management System; and
May employ additional staff in accordance with the budget.

Except for employees described in subparagraph (ii) or (iii) of this paragraph, the employees shall be skilled service employees subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern skilled service employees.
An employee is in the professional service and subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern professional service employees if the position:

sub-subparagraph.text: Requires knowledge of an advanced type in a field of science or learning customarily acquired by a course of specialized intellectual instruction and study; and
Normally requires a professional license, an advanced degree, or both.

subparagraph.text: An employee is in the management service and subject to the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern management service employees if the position:

sub-subparagraph.text: Primarily involves direct responsibility for the oversight and management of personnel and financial resources;
Requires the exercise of discretion and independent judgment; and
Is not in the executive service.

paragraph.text: The Board may retain the services of consultants, administrators, and other personnel, as necessary, to administer the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan.
The budget for the Program, the Board, and its staff is subject to review by the General Assembly for information purposes only.

subsection.text: The Board may adopt any regulations that the Board considers necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle or Subtitle 19A or Subtitle 19B of this title.
In addition, the Board may:

paragraph.text: Adopt an official seal;
Sue and be sued;
Execute contracts and other necessary instruments;
Hold, buy, and sell instruments, obligations, securities, and other investments consistent with its comprehensive investment plan;

Enter into agreements with eligible institutions of higher education and other public or private entities for the promotion, administration, or marketing of the Program, the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Invest funds not required for immediate disbursement;
Solicit and accept gifts, grants, loans, or other aid from any source or participate in any government program for purposes consistent with this subtitle and Subtitles 19A and 19B of this title;

Subject to the review of the General Assembly, impose and collect reasonable administrative fees for any transactions under the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan or involving prepaid contracts or transactions affecting the Program, the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Procure insurance against any loss of assets of the Program, the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Endorse insurance coverage written exclusively for the purpose of protecting:

subparagraph.text: A prepaid contract under the Trust and the account holder and the qualified beneficiary of the contract; or
An investment account under the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan, and the account holder and qualified designated beneficiary of the investment account;

paragraph.text: Designate terms under which money may be withdrawn from the Program, the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Establish additional procedural and substantive requirements for participation in and the administration or marketing of the Program, the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Appear on the Board’s own behalf before other boards, commissions, or other governmental agencies; and
Take any other action that the Board considers appropriate to implement and administer the Program, the Trust, the Plan, or the Broker–Dealer Plan.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt a comprehensive investment plan for the administration of the Trust.
The plan shall specify the investment policies used by the Board in the administration of the Trust.
Assets of the Trust shall be invested in accordance with the comprehensive investment plan.

The comprehensive investment plan must indicate the percentage of assets that shall be held in each class of investment, the amount of funds held in any cash pool, the amount of funds held in fixed assets investments, the amount of funds held in equity investments, and the percentage and dollar value of assets placed with outside managers.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any law restricting the deposit or investment of State money, the Board may place assets of the Trust in savings accounts or may use the assets to purchase fixed or variable life insurance or annuity contracts, securities, evidence of indebtedness, or other investment products pursuant to the comprehensive investment plan.
Any insurance, annuity contracts, savings, or other investment products procured by the Board shall be underwritten and offered in compliance with applicable federal and State laws.

subsection.text: The Board shall make every effort to invest the assets of the Trust in a manner that earns, at a minimum, sufficient earnings to generate the difference between the prepaid amount under prepaid contracts and the average in-State tuition costs at public institutions of higher education in the State at the time that the benefits are exercised.
The comprehensive investment plan shall provide for the Trust to be administered in an actuarially sound manner to assure that the Board may defray obligations of the Trust.
The Board shall review the comprehensive investment plan at least annually to assure that the Trust remains actuarially sound.

The Board may contract with an investment advisory or management company for the investment and management of the Trust as long as the Trust is administered in accordance with the comprehensive investment plan.
The Board:

paragraph.text: Shall preserve, invest, and expend the assets of the Trust solely for the purposes of this subtitle; and
May not loan, transfer, or use the assets for any other purpose of the State.

subsection.text: The Trust is not subject to § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Unless the Board provides otherwise by regulation, the Board shall use the proceeds in the Trust in the following order:

paragraph.text: To pay eligible institutions of higher education in accordance with the Board’s obligations under prepaid contracts;
To refund money on the termination of prepaid contracts; and
To pay the operating expenses of the Board.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the Board determines after an annual review that the market value of Trust assets exceeds the amount necessary to satisfy all scheduled payments currently due or scheduled to become due under all prepaid contracts by 30% or more, the Board may provide for a rebate from the excess to account holders of existing prepaid contracts in an amount to be determined by the Board.
The Board may not rebate any amount to account holders if, within the 5 years immediately preceding the proposed rebate:

subparagraph.text: The Board has requested an appropriation under § 18-1906.1 of this subtitle; or
The Trust has failed to repay to the State any appropriation under § 18-1906.1 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: If the current prepaid contract obligations of the Trust exceed the market value of Trust assets, at the request of the Board the Governor shall include in the annual budget bill submitted to the General Assembly an appropriation in the amount determined under subsection (b) of this section.

The appropriation to be included in the budget bill under subsection (a) of this section shall equal the difference between the current prepaid contract obligations and the market value of Trust assets.
For purposes of this section, the current prepaid contract obligations and the market value of Trust assets:

paragraph.text: Shall be determined as of June 30 of the calendar year that ended before the beginning of the fiscal year for which the appropriation is requested; and
Shall be verified by the report of the independent outside auditor required under § 18-1916 of this subtitle.
The amount appropriated under this section shall be deposited into the Trust.
All amounts paid into the Trust under this section shall constitute and be accounted for as advances to the Trust.

Subject to the rights of the Trust’s contract holders, amounts appropriated under this section shall be repaid to the State without interest in equal amounts in each of the next 2 fiscal years succeeding the one for which the appropriation was made.

If the appropriation in the State budget as enacted by the General Assembly is less than the amount specified under subsection (b) of this section, the Board may adjust the terms of subsequent or current prepaid contracts to ensure continued actuarial soundness of the Trust.

subsection.text: In this section, “fiduciary” means:

paragraph.text: A member of the Board; or
An employee of the Program or the Trust who exercises any discretionary authority or control over:

subparagraph.text: The management or administration of the Trust; or
The management or disposition of the assets of the Trust.

subsection.text: A fiduciary shall discharge the fiduciary’s duties with respect to the Trust:

paragraph.text: Solely in the interest of the participants;
For the exclusive purposes of providing benefits to the participants and providing reasonable expenses of administering the Trust;

With the care, skill, prudence, and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing, that a prudent person acting in a like capacity and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise of a like character with like aims;
By diversifying the investments of the Trust so as to minimize the risk of large losses, unless under the circumstances it is clearly prudent not to do so;
In accordance with the laws governing the Trust; and
In accordance with the documents and instruments governing the Trust to the extent that the documents and instruments are consistent with this subtitle.

subsection.text: In exercising authority, control, or discretion with respect to the Trust, a fiduciary may not:

paragraph.text: Use the assets of the Trust for the fiduciary’s own interest or account;
Act in a transaction involving the Trust on behalf of a person, or represent a person, if the interests of the person are adverse to the interests of the Trust or the interests of participants;
Receive any consideration for the fiduciary’s own account from a person dealing with the Trust in connection with a transaction involving the assets of the Trust; or
Become an endorser or surety or, in any manner, an obligor, for money lent to or borrowed from the Board.

subsection.text: The Board shall purchase a bond for each fiduciary in accordance with Title 9, Subtitle 17 of the State Government Article.
Unless a fiduciary is bonded, the fiduciary may not exercise custody or control of any assets of the Trust.
A fiduciary may not allow another fiduciary to act in violation of this section.
The Board shall establish prepaid contracts under the Trust to provide for the advance payment of tuition at:

paragraph.text: A community college;
A 4-year college;
A university; or
Any combination of a community college, college, or university.

For the purpose of entering into a prepaid contract, either the account holder or the qualified beneficiary must be a resident of Maryland or of the District of Columbia at the time that the account holder enters into the prepaid contract.
For the purposes of determining residency for the purchase of a prepaid contract:

subparagraph.text: For residency in Maryland, “resident” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of the Tax - General Article; and
For residency in the District of Columbia, “resident” has the meaning stated in § 47-1801.04 of the District of Columbia Code Annotated.

subsection.text: The cost of a prepaid contract shall be based on:

paragraph.text: The average current in-State tuition costs at the time the prepaid contract is purchased at public institutions of higher education in the State;
The number of years expected to elapse between the purchase of a prepaid contract and the use of the benefits of the prepaid contract; and
The projected tuition costs at the time that the benefits will be exercised.

subsection.text: Each prepaid contract made under the provisions of this subtitle shall include the following provisions:

paragraph.text: The amount of each payment and the number of payments required from an account holder;
The terms and conditions under which account holders shall remit payments, including the dates of the payments;
Provisions for late payment charges and defaults;
Penalties for early withdrawal from the Trust;
The amount and terms of any administrative fees that must be paid by the account holder or the beneficiary;
The name and date of birth of the qualified beneficiary on whose behalf the contract is made;
Terms and conditions for a substitution for the qualified beneficiary originally named;
Terms and conditions for the termination of the prepaid contract;
The time period during which the qualified beneficiary may claim benefits from the Trust;
The maximum number of undergraduate semester hours that are prepaid under the prepaid contract, based on in-State tuition at a public institution of higher education in the State;
All other rights and obligations of the account holder and the Trust; and
Any other terms and conditions that the Board considers necessary or appropriate.

subsection.text: The Board shall allow the conversion of a prepaid contract from one tuition plan or payment option to a different tuition plan or payment option.

The Board shall allow excess prepaid contract benefits due to receipt of a scholarship, tuition remission, or early graduation from college to be used toward the payment of other qualified higher education expenses, as specified by the Board, at an eligible institution of higher education.
The Board shall allow the transfer of funds from the Trust to any other qualified State tuition program or from any other qualified State tuition program to the Trust, in accordance with federal law.

The Board shall set procedures to ensure that contributions to the Trust plus contributions or payments to other qualified State tuition programs do not exceed a total maximum amount determined by § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code for contributions to multiple qualified State tuition programs.

paragraph.text: The Board shall issue refunds as specified in this section.
Unless authorized by the Board or under subsection (b) of this section, a refund may not exceed the amount paid into the Trust by the account holder.

subsection.text: A refund equal to the same benefits as provided by the prepaid contract, minus any amount paid out of the funds of the Trust on behalf of the qualified beneficiary and for reasonable administrative charges, shall be made if the beneficiary:

paragraph.text: Is awarded a scholarship or tuition remission that covers benefits provided under the prepaid contract; or
Dies or suffers from a disability which prevents the beneficiary from attending an institution of higher education within the time allowed by this subtitle.
A reduced refund of the contributions made to the Trust, as determined by the Board, shall be made if:

subparagraph.text: The beneficiary does not attend an institution of higher education;
Benefits are not exercised under the contract within a time specified in the contract; or
The prepaid contract is canceled by the account holder.

paragraph.text: The time that a qualified beneficiary spends in active duty as a member of the United States armed forces shall be added to the time period allowed to exercise the benefits under a prepaid contract before a termination under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

section.text: The Board, Trust, and prepaid contracts issued under this subtitle are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Article.
The assets and income of the Trust are exempt from State and local taxation.

subsection.text: In this section, “person” does not include the State.
A person may not attach, execute, garnish, or otherwise seize any current or future benefit under a prepaid contract or any asset of the Trust.

Nothing in this subtitle or in any prepaid contract may be construed as a promise or guarantee by the Board of admission to, continued enrollment at, or graduation from an institution of higher education.

The actual tuition rate charged to a qualified beneficiary shall be determined at the time of enrollment in accordance with the residency policy adopted by the governing board of the institution of higher education at which the qualified beneficiary enrolls.

section.text: The State and its agencies or any local government in the State may agree, by contract or otherwise, to remit payments on behalf of an employee toward a prepaid contract through payroll deductions.

paragraph.text: The Legislative Auditor shall audit the Trust as provided under Title 2, Subtitle 12 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall cause an audit of the Trust to be made by an outside independent auditor annually.
The Board shall pay for the audit required under paragraph (2) of this subsection.
Within 120 days after the close of each fiscal year, the Board shall submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly a report including:

subparagraph.text: The audit of the outside independent auditor;
A financial accounting of the Trust, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: The annual review of the comprehensive investment plan which shall include:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The status of the investment program, including investment income matched to projected enrollment costs under the existing prepaid contracts;
The assets held in each class of investment, the amount of funds held in any cash pool, the amount of funds held in fixed assets investments, and the amount of funds held in equity investments;
The percentage and dollar value of assets placed with outside managers;
The income produced by each class of investment; and
The income produced by each investment manager; and

sub-subparagraph.text: A detailed account of the operating and administrative budget for the Trust, which shall include a complete list of revenue sources and expenditures detailing the line item expenditures for:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Salaries, wages, and fringe benefits;
Technical and special fees;
Communication;
Travel;
Contractual services;
Supplies and materials;
Equipment;
Fixed charges; and
Other expenses.

subparagraph.text: The number of prepaid contracts entered into during the previous fiscal year;
Efforts by the Board in marketing the Trust of prepaid contracts; and
Any recommendations of the Board concerning the operation of the Trust.

paragraph.text: The Board shall make available to each account holder a copy of a summary of the report and the option to purchase the full report at a nominal charge.

subsection.text: The audit required by subsection (a)(2) of this section and the report required by subsection (b) of this section may be combined with any other audit or report for the same fiscal year required to be submitted by the Board to the Governor and the General Assembly.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Account holder” means the person who established an investment account on behalf of a qualified designated beneficiary.
“Board” means the College Savings Plans of Maryland Board established under § 18-1904 of this title.
“Eligible educational institution” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.

“Investment account” means an account established by an account holder under this subtitle on behalf of a qualified designated beneficiary for the purpose of applying distributions toward qualified higher education expenses at eligible educational institutions.
“Plan” means the Maryland College Investment Plan established under this subtitle.
“Qualified designated beneficiary” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Qualified higher education expenses” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Qualified state tuition program” has the meaning stated in § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code.
There is a Maryland College Investment Plan.

The purpose of the Plan is to allow contributions to an investment account established for the purposes of meeting the qualified higher education expenses of the qualified designated beneficiary of the account.

paragraph.text: The Board shall administer, manage, promote, and market the Plan.
The Board shall administer the Plan in compliance with Internal Revenue Service standards for qualified State tuition programs.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt procedures that the Board considers necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.
The Board shall adopt procedures relating to:

paragraph.text: Application procedures for participation in the Plan;
Start-up costs incurred by the State for the development of the Plan with these costs to be reimbursed to the State by the Plan;
Early withdrawals, so that there will be no major detriment to the remaining account holders in the Plan; and
Transfer of funds from the Plan to other qualified State tuition programs and from other qualified State tuition programs to the Plan in accordance with federal law.

subsection.text: At least annually, the Board shall issue to each account holder a statement that provides a separate accounting for each qualified designated beneficiary providing the following information with respect to each account:

paragraph.text: The beginning balance;
Contributions to the account;
Withdrawals from the account during the previous year; and
Ending investment account value.
The Board may issue requests for proposals to evaluate and determine the means for the administration, management, promotion, or marketing of the Plan.
The Board shall consider proposals that meet the following criteria:

subparagraph.text: Ability to develop and administer an investment program of a nature similar to the objectives of the Plan;
Ability to administer financial programs with individual account records and reporting;
Ability to market the Plan to Maryland residents;
Ability to market the Plan to nonresidents of Maryland; and

Ability to coordinate the Plan with other programs or informational services considered beneficial by the Board, including the Maryland Prepaid College Trust established under Subtitle 19 of this title.

paragraph.text: The Board may require an initial application fee to be used for administrative costs of the Plan.
The Board may require additional fees associated with the expenses of the Plan.
Contributions to the Plan on behalf of a qualified designated beneficiary may not exceed the maximum amount determined by the Board to be in accordance with § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code.
Contributions to the Plan may be made only in cash or cash equivalent.
The Plan shall include provisions for automatic contributions.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt procedures to ensure that contributions to the Plan plus contributions or payments to other qualified State tuition programs do not exceed a total maximum amount determined under § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code for contributions to multiple qualified State tuition programs.

paragraph.text: The Plan:

subparagraph.text: Shall be established in the form determined by the Board; and
May be established as a trust to be declared by the Board.

paragraph.text: The Plan may be divided into multiple investment portfolios.

If the Plan is divided into multiple portfolios as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the debts, liabilities, obligations, and expenses incurred, contracted for, or otherwise existing with respect to a particular portfolio shall be enforceable against the assets of that portfolio only and not against the assets of the Plan generally, if:

subparagraph.text: Distinct records are maintained for each portfolio; and
The assets associated with each portfolio are accounted for separately from the other assets of the Plan.

subsection.text: A Maryland resident or a nonresident of Maryland may participate in and benefit from the Plan.
Distributions shall be requested by the account holder.

paragraph.text: The debts, contracts, and obligations of the Plan are not the contracts, debts, or obligations of the State and neither the faith and credit nor taxing power of the State is pledged directly or indirectly or contingently, morally or otherwise, to the payment of the debts, contracts, and obligations.

The Board cannot directly or indirectly or contingently obligate, morally or otherwise, the State to levy or pledge any form of taxation whatsoever for the debts and obligations of the Plan or to make any appropriation for the payment of the debts and obligations of the Plan.

subsection.text: Neither the State nor any eligible educational institution shall be liable for any losses or shortage of funds in the event that the account holder’s investment account balance is insufficient to meet the tuition requirements of an institution attended by the qualified designated beneficiary.
Moneys of the Plan may not be considered moneys of the State or deposited in the State Treasury.
Moneys of the Plan may not be considered moneys of or commingled with the Maryland Prepaid College Trust.
Moneys of the Plan may not be considered moneys of or commingled with the Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan.

section.text: The Board, Plan, and investment accounts issued under this subtitle are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Article.
The assets and income of the Maryland College Investment Plan are exempt from State and local taxation.

subsection.text: In this section, “person” does not include the State.
A person may not attach, execute, garnish, or otherwise seize any current or future benefit under an investment account or any asset of the Plan.

paragraph.text: The Legislative Auditor shall audit the Plan as provided under Title 2, Subtitle 12 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall obtain an annual audit report from service providers.
Within 120 days after the close of each fiscal year, the Board shall submit to the Governor and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly a report including:

subparagraph.text: A financial accounting of the Plan, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: An annual review of the Plan which shall include:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The status of the investment program;
The assets held in each class of investment;
The percentage and dollar value of assets placed with outside managers;
The income produced by each class of investment;
The income produced by each investment manager;
The total deposits into the Plan for the past year; and
The total withdrawals from the Plan for the past year; and

sub-subparagraph.text: A detailed account of the operating and administrative budget for the Plan, which shall include a complete list of revenue sources and expenditures detailing the line item expenditures for:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Salaries, wages, and fringe benefits;
Technical and special fees;
Communication;
Travel;
Contractual services;
Supplies and materials;
Equipment;
Fixed charges; and
Other expenses;

subparagraph.text: The number of new account holders during the previous fiscal year;
Efforts in marketing the Plan; and
Any recommendations of the Board concerning the operation of the Plan.

paragraph.text: The Board shall make available to each account holder a copy of a summary of the report and the option to purchase the full report at a nominal charge.

subsection.text: The audit required by subsection (a)(2) of this section and the report required by subsection (b) of this section, at the Board’s discretion, may be combined with any other audit or report for the same fiscal year required to be submitted by the Board to the Governor and the General Assembly.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Account holder” means the person who established an investment account on behalf of a qualified designated beneficiary.
“Board” means the College Savings Plans of Maryland Board established under § 18–1904 of this title.
“Broker–Dealer Plan” means the Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan established under this subtitle.
“Eligible educational institution” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.

“Investment account” means an account established by an account holder under this subtitle on behalf of a qualified designated beneficiary for the purpose of applying distributions toward qualified higher education expenses at eligible educational institutions.
“Qualified designated beneficiary” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Qualified higher education expenses” has the meaning stated in § 529(e) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Qualified State tuition program” has the meaning stated in § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code.
The Board may establish a Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan.

The purpose of the Broker–Dealer Plan is to provide for a broker–dealer distributed vehicle that would allow contributions to an investment account established for the purposes of meeting the qualified higher education expenses of the qualified designated beneficiary of the account.

paragraph.text: The Board shall administer, manage, and promote the Broker–Dealer Plan.
The Board shall administer the Broker–Dealer Plan in compliance with Internal Revenue Service standards for qualified State tuition programs.
The Board shall adopt procedures relating to:

subparagraph.text: Enrollment procedures for participation in the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Start–up costs incurred by the State for the development of the Broker–Dealer Plan with these costs to be reimbursed to the State by the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Early withdrawals so that there will be no major detriment to the remaining account holders in the Broker–Dealer Plan; and
Transfer of funds from the Broker–Dealer Plan to other qualified State tuition programs and from other qualified State tuition programs to the Broker–Dealer Plan in accordance with federal law; and

paragraph.text: The Board shall adopt any other procedures that the Board considers necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

subsection.text: At least annually, the Board shall issue to each account holder a statement that provides a separate accounting for each qualified designated beneficiary providing the following information with respect to each account:

paragraph.text: The beginning balance;
Contributions to the account;
Withdrawals from the account during the previous year; and
Ending investment account value.
The Board may issue requests for proposals to evaluate and determine the means for the administration, management, promotion, or marketing of the Broker–Dealer Plan.
The Board shall consider proposals that meet the following criteria:

subparagraph.text: Ability to develop and administer an investment program of a nature similar to the objectives of the Broker–Dealer Plan;
Ability to administer financial programs with individual account records and reporting; and
Ability to market the Broker–Dealer Plan to Maryland residents and, at the Board’s discretion, nonresidents of Maryland.

paragraph.text: The Board may require an initial enrollment fee to be used for administrative costs of the Broker–Dealer Plan.
The Board may require additional fees associated with the expenses of the Broker–Dealer Plan.

Contributions to the Broker–Dealer Plan on behalf of a qualified designated beneficiary may not exceed the maximum amount determined by the Board to be in accordance with § 529 of the Internal Revenue Code.
Contributions to the Broker–Dealer Plan may be made only in cash or cash equivalents.
The Broker–Dealer Plan shall include provisions for automatic contributions.
The Broker–Dealer Plan:

subparagraph.text: May be established as one or more separate plans as determined by the Board;
If established by the Board, shall be established in the form determined by the Board;
Shall be marketed and promoted under the name or names determined by the Board; and
May be established as one or more trusts to be declared by the Board.

paragraph.text: The Broker–Dealer Plan may be divided into multiple investment options.

subsection.text: A Maryland resident or, at the Board’s discretion, a nonresident of Maryland may participate in and benefit from the Broker–Dealer Plan.
Distributions shall be requested by the account holder.

paragraph.text: The debts, contracts, and obligations of the Broker–Dealer Plan are not the contracts, debts, or obligations of the State, and neither the faith and credit nor taxing power of the State is pledged directly or indirectly or contingently, morally or otherwise, to the payment of the debts, contracts, and obligations.

The Board cannot directly or indirectly or contingently obligate, morally or otherwise, the State to levy or pledge any form of taxation whatsoever for the debts and obligations of the Broker–Dealer Plan or to make any appropriation for the payment of the debts and obligations of the Broker–Dealer Plan.

subsection.text: Neither the State nor any eligible educational institution shall be liable for any losses or shortage of funds in the event that the account holder’s investment account balance is insufficient to meet the tuition requirements of an institution attended by the qualified designated beneficiary.
Moneys of the Broker–Dealer Plan may not be considered moneys of the State or deposited in the State Treasury.
Moneys of the Broker–Dealer Plan may not be considered moneys of or commingled with the Maryland Prepaid College Trust.
Moneys of the Broker–Dealer Plan may not be considered moneys of or commingled with the Maryland College Investment Plan.
The Board, the Broker–Dealer Plan, and the investment accounts issued under this subtitle are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Article.
The assets and income of the Maryland Broker–Dealer College Investment Plan are exempt from State and local taxation.
In this section, “person” does not include the State.
A person may not attach, execute, garnish, or otherwise seize any current or future benefit under an investment account or any asset of the Broker–Dealer Plan.
The legislative auditor shall audit the Broker–Dealer Plan as provided under Title 2, Subtitle 12 of the State Government Article.
The Board shall obtain an annual audit report from service provider(s) within six months of the end of such service provider’s reporting period.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Office” means the Office of Student Financial Assistance as defined in § 18-101(c) of this title.

“Regular undergraduate program” means an academic program of study in an institution of higher education at or below the baccalaureate level leading to either an associate’s degree or bachelor’s degree.

paragraph.text: “Service obligation” means employment in the State in an occupation directly related to the eligible program of study as determined by the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
“Service obligation” does not mean paid student internships, paid fellowships, or volunteer service.

subsection.text: There is a program of Maryland Science and Technology Scholarships in this State that are awarded under this subtitle. The Office shall annually select students who have the greatest potential for academic success in higher education and offer a scholarship to each student to be used at a Maryland higher education institution of the student’s choice, if the recipient meets the following qualifications:

paragraph.text: Qualifies academically as follows:

subparagraph.text: Has a secondary school transcript indicating an overall grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale or its equivalent after completion of the first semester of the senior year;
Intends to enroll or is enrolled as a full-time student in an academic program as designated by the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
Has graduated from a secondary school;

paragraph.text: Is a Maryland resident and was a Maryland resident at the time of graduating from secondary school;
Is accepted for admission in a regular undergraduate program at a Maryland higher education institution in the State;

Begins attending an eligible Maryland higher education institution within 5 years of completing secondary school or, failing to do so, provides evidence satisfactory to the Office of extenuating circumstances;
Agrees to the conditions provided in subsection (c) of this section; and
Accepts any other conditions attached to the award and satisfies any additional criteria the Commission may establish.
The annual scholarship award shall be in the amount of $1,000 for a student enrolled at a 2-year eligible institution or $3,000 for a student enrolled at a 4-year eligible institution.
If accepted by the eligible student, each award may be renewed on an annual basis for a maximum of 3 years after the original award if the recipient:

subparagraph.text: Remains a resident of the State;
Attends a Maryland higher education institution in the State;
Is enrolled as a full-time undergraduate student and takes at least 12 semester hours of courses each semester or its equivalent as determined by the Office;
Maintains a 3.0 grade point average on an academic year basis or, failing to do so, provides evidence satisfactory to the Office, of extreme extenuating circumstances;
Is making satisfactory progress toward a degree as determined by the institution; and
Maintains the standards of the institution.

paragraph.text: Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, each recipient of a Maryland Science and Technology Scholarship who is enrolled in a baccalaureate degree program may renew the annual award four times if the recipient is enrolled in an undergraduate academic program that, as determined by the institution, requires 5 years to complete.
Subject to the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection, each award may be renewed on an annual basis for a maximum of 2 years for students enrolled in an associate degree program.

subsection.text: A recipient of an award made under this section shall receive the award for each year indicated in which the recipient is eligible if:

paragraph.text: The recipient signs an agreement at the time of the initial award to:

subparagraph.text: Commence employment in the State within 1 year after completion of undergraduate studies for 1 year for each year that the scholarship was awarded; and
Repay the State the amounts awarded under this subtitle as set forth in § 18-112 of this title if the recipient does not:

sub-subparagraph.text: Satisfy the degree requirements of the eligible academic program or fulfill other requirements as provided in this subtitle; and
Perform the service obligation for 1 year for each year that the recipient has a scholarship awarded under this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: The service obligation begins after graduation and cannot be fulfilled prior to graduation from an eligible institution.

section.text: A Maryland Science and Technology Scholarship may be used for tuition and mandatory fees at any eligible institution.

Each year after consulting with the Department of Business and Economic Development, the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, and the appropriate commission advisory boards and evaluating such factors as high economic growth and the needs of Maryland’s science and technology industry and business community, the Commission shall establish a list of academic programs eligible for the Maryland Science and Technology Scholarship Program.
Funds for the Maryland Science and Technology Scholarship Program shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.

On or before May 1 of each year, the Office shall send each Senator and each Delegate a list of individuals in each legislative district to whom Maryland Science and Technology Scholarships are awarded.
The Office of Student Financial Assistance shall publicize the availability of Maryland Science and Technology Scholarships.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible institution” means a public or private nonprofit institution of higher education in this State that possesses a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
“Office” means the Office of Student Financial Assistance as defined in § 18–101(c) of this title.

paragraph.text: “Service obligation” means to teach full time in the State as a teacher in a Maryland public elementary or secondary school.
“Service obligation” does not mean employment as teaching assistants, volunteer service, paid fellowships, or internships.

section.text: There is a program of Maryland Teacher Scholarships that are awarded under this subtitle for students who pledge to work as public elementary and secondary school teachers in this State upon completion of their studies.

subsection.text: The Office shall annually select eligible students and offer a scholarship to each student selected to be used at an eligible institution of their choice.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a recipient of the Maryland Teacher Scholarship shall:

subparagraph.text: Be a Maryland resident;

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, be accepted for admission or currently enrolled at an eligible institution as a full–time or part–time undergraduate or graduate student pursuing a course of study or program in an academic discipline leading to a Maryland professional teacher’s certificate;

sub-subparagraph.text: For a student currently enrolled in high school, have earned an overall grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale or its equivalent after completion of the first semester of the senior year; or

For a student currently enrolled as a full–time undergraduate student, have maintained a grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale and have been making satisfactory progress toward a degree in an academic discipline leading to a Maryland professional teacher’s certificate;

subparagraph.text: Sign a letter of intent to perform the service obligation upon completion of the recipient’s required studies;
Accept any other conditions attached to the award; and
Satisfy any additional criteria the Commission may establish.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, an individual who, at the time the individual is scheduled to matriculate at an eligible institution, will have been employed as a teaching assistant at a public elementary or secondary school in the State for at least 2 years:

subparagraph.text: May apply for a Maryland Teacher Scholarship under this subtitle; and
Is eligible to hold a Maryland Teacher Scholarship as a full–time or part–time undergraduate or graduate student.

subsection.text: A recipient of the Maryland Teacher Scholarship may not hold a Maryland professional teacher’s certificate.

paragraph.text: Applicants who are secondary school students shall provide a high school transcript after completion of the first semester of their senior year.
Applicants who are currently enrolled in an eligible institution shall provide the most recent college transcript, or if not applicable, the applicant may submit a final high school transcript.
Applicants who are not currently enrolled in an eligible institution, but who are high school graduates, shall provide a final high school transcript.

Applicants who are high school graduates and are not currently enrolled in an eligible institution, but have completed some courses at an eligible institution, shall provide the most recent college transcript.
Applicants who are not currently enrolled in an eligible institution, but who are college graduates, shall provide a final college transcript.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the recipient of a Maryland Teacher Scholarship shall repay the Commission the funds received as set forth in § 18-112 of this title if the recipient does not:

paragraph.text: Satisfy the degree requirements of the eligible course of study or program or fulfill other requirements as provided in this subtitle;
Perform the service obligation for 1 year for each year that the recipient has a scholarship awarded under this subtitle; and
Become professionally certified to teach in the State of Maryland within the time period specified by the Commission in consultation with the Maryland Department of Education.

subsection.text: The Office shall forgive a recipient of a Maryland Teacher Scholarship for 2 years of an award if:

paragraph.text: The recipient has taken the teacher certification examination, approved by the State Board of Education, in 2 consecutive years; and
The recipient fails to pass the teacher certification examination within the time period specified by the Commission in accordance with subsection (a)(3) of this section.

section.text: The annual scholarship award shall be in the amount of:

paragraph.text: $2,000 for a full-time undergraduate student, or $1,000 for a part-time undergraduate student, enrolled at a 2-year eligible institution;
$5,000 for a full-time undergraduate or graduate student enrolled in a 4-year eligible institution; or
$2,500 for a part-time undergraduate or graduate student enrolled at a 4-year eligible institution.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, each recipient of a Maryland Teacher Scholarship may renew the award three times if the recipient:

paragraph.text: Continues to be a resident of the State;
Continues to be a full-time or part-time undergraduate or graduate student at an eligible institution as determined by the Office;

Has achieved a cumulative grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale and maintains this minimum cumulative grade point average throughout the remainder of this award, or failing to do so, provides evidence of extenuating circumstances;
In the judgment of the institution, is making satisfactory progress toward a degree; and
Maintains the standards of the institution.

Each recipient of a Maryland Teacher Scholarship who is enrolled in an associate degree program as permitted in this subtitle may renew the award two times if the recipient is enrolled in an associate degree program that, as determined by the institution, requires 3 years to complete.

Each recipient of the Maryland Teacher Scholarship may renew the annual award four times if the recipient is enrolled in a course of study that, as determined by the institution, requires 5 years to complete.

section.text: A Maryland Teacher Scholarship may be used for tuition and mandatory fees at any eligible institution.
Funds for the Maryland Teacher Scholarship program shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Commission by the Governor.
The Office of Student Financial Assistance shall publicize the availability of Maryland Teacher Scholarships.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible institution” means a public or private nonprofit institution of higher education in this State that possesses a certificate of approval from the Maryland Higher Education Commission.

“Regular undergraduate program” means an academic program of study in an institution of higher education at or below the baccalaureate level leading to either an associate’s degree or bachelor’s degree.
“Service obligation” means full-time employment within the State.
There is a program of Maryland HOPE Scholarships in this State that are awarded under this subtitle.
The Office shall publicize the availability of Maryland HOPE Scholarships.

section.text: Each recipient of a Maryland HOPE Scholarship shall:

paragraph.text: Be accepted for admission in a regular undergraduate program at an eligible institution in the State;
Be a resident of the State;
Earn an overall grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale or its equivalent after completion of the first semester of the senior year;
Begin attending an eligible institution within 2 years of completing high school or, failing to do so, provide evidence satisfactory to the Office of extenuating circumstances;
Enroll as a full-time student at an eligible institution;
Have an annual total family income of $95,000 or below;
Accept any other conditions attached to the award; and
Satisfy any additional criteria the Maryland Higher Education Commission may establish.

subsection.text: The annual scholarship award shall be in the amount of $1,000 for a student enrolled at a 2-year eligible institution or $3,000 for a student enrolled in a 4-year eligible institution.

A student who transfers from a 2-year eligible institution to a 4-year eligible institution may receive an annual scholarship award in the amount of $3,000 once the student is enrolled at the 4-year eligible institution.

section.text: A Maryland HOPE Scholarship may be used at an eligible institution in the State.

subsection.text: Each recipient of a Maryland HOPE Scholarship may hold the award for 5 years if the recipient:

paragraph.text: Continues to be a resident of the State;
Continues to be a full-time student at an eligible institution in the State and takes at least 12 semester hours of courses each semester or its equivalent as determined by the Office;

Upon completion of the freshman year, has achieved a cumulative grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale, and maintains this minimum cumulative grade point average throughout the remainder of the award, or failing to do so, provides evidence satisfactory to the Office of extenuating circumstances;
In the judgment of the institution, is making satisfactory progress toward a degree; and
Maintains the standards of the institution.

subsection.text: Each recipient of a Maryland HOPE Scholarship who is enrolled in an associate degree program as permitted in this subtitle may hold the award for 3 years if the same conditions of subsection (a) of this section are met.

Each recipient of a Maryland HOPE Scholarship who transfers from a 2-year eligible institution to a 4-year eligible institution may hold the award for a total of 5 years, including the years at both the 2-year eligible institution and the 4-year eligible institution, if the same conditions of subsection (a) of this section are met.

A recipient of an award made under this section shall receive the award for each year indicated in which the recipient is eligible if the recipient signs an agreement at the time of the initial award to:

paragraph.text: Commence employment in the State within 1 year after completion of undergraduate studies for 1 year for each year that the scholarship was awarded; and
Repay the State the amounts awarded under this subtitle as set forth in § 18-112 of this title if the recipient does not:

subparagraph.text: Satisfy the degree requirements of the eligible institution or fulfill other requirements as provided in this subtitle; and
Perform the service obligation for 1 year for each year that the recipient has a scholarship awarded under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The service obligation begins after graduation and cannot be fulfilled prior to graduation from an eligible institution.

section.text: On or before May 1 of each year, the Office shall send each Senator and each Delegate a list of individuals in each legislative district to whom Maryland HOPE Scholarships are awarded.
A Maryland HOPE Scholarship may be used for tuition and mandatory fees at any eligible institution.
Funds for the Maryland HOPE Scholarship Program shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Maryland Higher Education Commission by the Governor.

subsection.text: The Maryland Higher Education Commission shall draft a plan to administer a Maryland HOPE Scholarship Program.
The Commission’s plan shall include:

paragraph.text: A 3-year schedule, beginning July 1, 2000, for the progressive implementation of the Maryland HOPE Scholarship Award to all eligible students; and
A priority list of the applicable fields of study which focuses on such factors as:

subparagraph.text: Economic need of the State;
Employment shortage areas of the State; and
Training and education capacity of the higher education institutions in Maryland.

subsection.text: The priority list shall be created in consultation with the appropriate advisory boards of the Commission, the Department of Business and Economic Development, and representatives of higher education and private industry.

section.text: The Maryland Higher Education Commission shall submit the plan for the implementation of the Maryland HOPE Scholarship Program to the Governor and the Legislative Policy Committee of the General Assembly by October 30, 1999.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Higher education loan” means any loan for undergraduate or graduate study leading to practice as a dentist that is obtained for tuition, educational expenses, or living expenses from:

paragraph.text: A college or university, government, or commercial source; or
An organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.

subsection.text: “Program” means the Maryland Dent-Care Program.
There is a program of higher education loan assistance grants to dentists in the State, known as the Maryland Dent-Care Program.
The purpose of the Program is to increase access to oral health services for underserved Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients by increasing the number of dentists who treat that population.
The Office shall administer the Program with the assistance of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, Office of Oral Health.
The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, Office of Oral Health shall:

paragraph.text: Recruit dentists to participate in the Program;

Determine if the private practice or clinical setting in which an applicant will practice is located near or readily accessible to underserved Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients and if the applicant qualifies for the Program;
Determine if each participant meets the Program requirements and serves the required number of Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients; and
Notify the Office of any findings made in accordance with the provisions of this subsection.

section.text: Each applicant for a Higher Education Loan Assistance Grant under this subtitle shall:

paragraph.text: Be licensed to practice in Maryland by the State Board of Dental Examiners;
Demonstrate financial need;
Be employed full time as a dentist;
